Damn Kurzgesagt, you guys really missed the mark here. I get that you wanted to portray GMOs as a potentially beneficial & powerful technology, but you certainly underplayed their real and potential detriments to society and the world. Comparing genetic modification in a lab to artificial selection over generations 'without the guesswork' is misleading at best. Moreover, I'm disappointed that you would mention how much of the valid concern over GMOs is based on how corporations are using them (not GMO's nutrition), even mentioning glyphosate, but then not go into detail about its origin in Agent Orange, relation to RoundUp, and effects on environmental and human health. Finally, I heard no mention of the problems with patented GMO crops mixing with normal crops nearby, and what that could mean for non-GMO farmers legally, as well as the host of unpredictable environmental consequences the come along with lab engineered DNA making its way into wild ecosystems/gene pools.

It's unfortunate that so many people will see your video and walk away thinking that anyone who doesn't want GMOs is scientifically ignorant. I'm all for dispelling ignorance, but at least be fair and honest in presenting both "sides" or pros and cons on a global topic this nuanced. While the facts that you do present may not be wrong, what you chose to omit speaks volumes. Having people understand that GMOs are another technology neither inherently good nor bad, is not the same as answering the question as to whether or not we should be supporting and encouraging or opposing and moving away from GMOs as a society.

The main problem with GMOs is not the direct health effect eating GMO crops has on the human body, but rather what GMO crops do to the soil and its organic content. Larger fruits and legumes simply means more nutrients being carried up from the soil. Poor waste management means that billions of tons of food waste is never composted and never reaches the agricultural fields, and so the nutritional content of the soil drops dramatically over time. This is augmented with chemical fertilizers and other poor farming practices necessary to keep the plant production high while depleting the soil entirely of its essential microbial life and organic content. These practices will only leave us with a barren landscape as within our own lifetimes, more and more crops will begin to fail, and more genetic modification will be introduced to try and circumvent the root problems. The truth is, if the soil were healthy, much less genetic modification would be needed. Just because a fruit is larger in size, this does not translate into higher overall nutritional content, but rather into foods with lower densities of nutrients and larger volumes of sugars. This means that to get the same nutritional content from a fruit, one has to eat larger quantities, contributing to obesity and other health risks. Without addressing nutrient profiles of GMO fruits and legumes, we are not really tackling the main issues, which are human and planetary wellbeing.

I think the issue comes from a simple concept, followed by a simple question: (read everything before you try to correct the following two items.)

We know that our bodies asses what a food is based on its genetics. We've known this for awhile.

If our body relies on it being able to identify food via its genetics, how can altering those genetics not result in our bodies either rejecting it or having problems due to it?

While I understand that the statement is an extreme over simplification, and the question is based upon that over simplification - many do not. As they actually are intelligent enough to understand a less simplified explanation of how our bodies handle foods we, as a society, have adopted this bad habit of assuming that people with questions are too stupid to understand the answers. Thus we simplify explanations down to being so overly simplified that a logical conclusion drawn from said explanation is completely wrong. That does not mean that the person making said logical connection is somehow stupid. Often? We are overly patronizing to people outside of our particular field. We assume that people are so horrendously stupid that they could never understand a proper explanation, and yet we then decide that they are stupid when they use the childlike explanation to draw an incorrect conclusion.

Once people can accept that, by and large, people are not actually as stupid as they think they are? We might begin entrusting people with actual answers. Once we begin to do that we may be surprised at how quickly the 'average person' becomes far more accepting of scientific and technological changes.

This is what I read on the other side of a post to GMO. They were talking about apples.
"Worse yet, it may also carry a heavier load of pesticide
residues than other conventional apples; it was produced
using a new, experimental and potentially hazardous new
genetic engineering technique; and threatens apple farm-
ers, particularly organic apple farmers. Apple growers and
consumers alike say they don’t need or want this GMO. Research shows that dsRNAs from food can remain intact through the digestion process and can enter the blood-
stream and cells. Once in cells, this dsRNA can affect how
they function. It is unclear what the unintended impacts on the cells might be, and according to Professor Judy Car-
man, whose research
focuses on genetically modified plants, “we won't know (about
the impacts) until we do thorough assessments, and these assessments have not yet been done. "
A problem masquerading as a solution. We also know that this apple has been engineered to
lack the natural browning enzyme that may help fight
diseases and pests, meaning farmers may have to use even sizes of apple orchards means that the risks of cross- pollination between GE apples and non-GMO apples
is high.25 In fact, studies show that cross-pollinating bees can travel several kilometers, and that other animals such as bats, squirrels, and birds could also spread pollen from
apple trees, and cross pollinate with crab apple trees. Farmers are also concerned that this “one bad apple”
could spoil the whole bunch -- harming sales here and abroad. Normally, when an apple is cut or bitten into, the ex-posed part will slowly brown. This natural browning is caused by an enzyme that produces melanin, polyphenol
oxidase, which gives cells a brown tint when exposed to oxygen. Scientists believe the browning may play an important role in helping apples to fend off pests and
disease.
The Arctic Apple®, on the other hand, was genetically engineered by the Canadian company Okanagan
Specialty Fruits to not brown for up to 15-18 days after being sliced, bruised or bitten.
How does this work? The company inserted a synthetic gene comprised of 4 natural PPO genes into an apple.
This gene is called “double-stranded RNA,” and its function is to “silence” the genes that govern the production of PPO. The apple’s own natural defense system attacks the inserted extra foreign gene and destroys both the copy and the original gene in the process. With no genes left
to create the browning chemical, the apple does not turn brown after it has been cut, and may look fresh when it is actually decaying.
There are insufficient long-term studies which show that consumption of genetically engineered food is safe for humans. Given that children are amongst the most sensitive to food allergens, it is critical that the first foods children eat are shown to be safe by independent, peer reviewed, long-term safety studies.

Most genetically engineered foods on the market today have no consumer benefits whatsoever; they are engineered to survive pesticides, and have greatly accelerated the use of pesticides such as glyphosate, dicamba and soon 2,4D, creating what environmental groups call a dangerous pesticide treadmill.

This is all part of the big plan, and most of you do not even have a clue. People who support GMOs are so blind to reality, swapping individual genes or sequences of genes, pulling it out of one organisms DNA and then putting it into another which causes all kinds of issues. The five major genetically modified food crops are corn, cotton, soy, canola and suga beets. All of these five are engineered by a trait called Herbicide tolerance . This is where they take a gene usually from a bacteria and put it into the DNA of the plants so that the plants can be sprayed with weed killers that would normally kill them. The crops absorb the weed killer and we eat it lol. The other types of crops are the BT crops (Bacillus Thuringiensis) which is again a poison or insecticide. It breaks open the belly of insects and kills them, it comes from a natural  soil bacteria. So they take the gene out of the bacteria, put it into the DNA of corn and cotton plants, so these crops become registered pesticides lol. From the poison is a chemical called Glyphosate which actually destroys our gut bacteria. Gut bacteria is majorly important as without it our body cannot produce Tryptophan (amino acid), and without that our bodies do not produce Serotonin. Of course without Serotonin our body will struggle to regulate blood sugar and vwalaaaa.... DIABETES!!! Another issue is that, if large corporations keep these crops to themselves, they'd gain an advantage which no other non-gmo company could compete with -- leading to a large advantage to already large corporations which have the power to produce these GMOs. As if that wasn't enough, genes could be changed in such a way that if they were mixed with other crops - they'd die. This means that large companies can also use their crops to sabotage the productions of other companies.

In order to solve this, I feel it's necessary for GMOs to be controlled by the government, with seeds and the like being distributed to anybody who wants them, along with the crops being regulated so that no unreasonable or damaging changes are made to the plant. This would also democratize the process of making GMOs, with everyone being able to access their benefits, nobody being able to unlawfully change them in a damaging way, and everyone being able to reap the benefits of the GMO seeds they sowed.

I feel that there is no doubt about the current industrial-level agriculture system being unsustainable, and in turn, dangerous. Widescale industrial processes are a good force on farming, as they're able to produce more food and feed everyone who needs it. But much like many things in life, it's about striking a balance. Since few of the corporations themselves are going to willingly employ these less effective but safer practices, there ought to be a regulating body to all of this.

The FAO (Food an Agriculture Organisation - UN) published these numbers :
- 854 Millions people suffering from hunger in the world (~11% of world population in 2021)
- 1.3 Billions tons of wasted food around the world (~35% of world food production)

The question is : Do we need to change the way we produce food or the way we consume food ?
The answer is : Both ! In fact, food waste is mostly not happening in our fridges but in the fields, factories, transport, shops.

- In the fields : We need perfect fruits and vegetables or else the retailers wont buy them.
- In the factories : If that cake is not perfectly round nobody will buy it.
- In transport : Crap ! The cooler on that truck was malfunctioning, we need to get rid of everything.
- In shops : The fruit section has to be full to be attractive for customer. Doesn't matter if half of it will rot.

As customers, we have some control over three of those factors of waste. If we reduce food waste by just a third, we have enough food to feed everyone on earth ! If we reduce it by 2/3, we can reduce agriculture intensification and the impact of diseases and use of pesticides and fertilizers.
My opinion about GMOs is simple : Lets try that before to try engineering life and taking the risk to spread those modifications to wild organisms with no actual idea of the repercussions for biodiversity.

It's not that it's GMO that's the problem. It's HOW they're modified. You can change food in so many ways that you can create highly deadly food to humans with minimal effort. Selective breeding limits the changes to the set which genetic crossover will allow. GMO manipulation puts no limit on the changes. You can create pig organs which possess human DNA. Such a state could never be accomplished without genetic engineering.

The risk is too high for till little reward for GMO food -- what do we gain if we already make plenty of food? Better taste? But one tweak could make a fruit carcinogenic and nobody would be the wiser for decades. All because you wanted to make the food artificially resistant to pests -- pests which will quickly evolve resistance anyway.

For medicine, the risk is worth it for the reward gained. It's literally the difference between life and death. Causing cancer in 30 years is not a major problem if you'll be dead in 2 years from a failed organ that could be replaced with a gmo substitute.

Risk/reward. That's the only question. For food, the rewards aren't enough for the risk. For medicine, the rewards are worth the risk.

Firstly, selective breeding crops or animals for better traits is NOT the same as taking the DNA from one species and randomly inserting it into another DNA with a gene gun; the latter is what GMOs are (google it). The science of how harmful GMOs are is considerable. Google Seralini study, which has been republished in a respected peer-reviewed journal since 2014 showing the detrimental effects of GMOs (google it) and the chemicals used to grow them.

Additionally, glyphosate (Roundup) herbicide is so widespread that it's found in the breast milk of mothers, and is found in mostly all processed foods that contain corn, soy, cottonseed oil, canola oil, among others.

If over 60 countries have either limited the use of GMOs or flat out banned them (google it), then there is a good reason, and the reasons are shocking. Instead of listening to someone who clearly doesn't know what he's talking about, try using your good ol' friend, Google, and do your own research.

Lastly, stay away from a website called the Genetic Literacy Project; it was created by Monsanto to dupe the public with misinformation and push out industry-led "science" to hide the harms from their lab-created failed experiment of GMOs.

Foods that have been developed for millions of years by nature are natural. However, when a natural food product's DNA is altered to make a corporation more money, it creates a myriad of unintended consequences that affect every living organism of life on the planet.

One thing this video doesn't touch on is the fact that all GMOs aren't made equal. GMOs within themselves aren't inherently bad, but they can be since humans are making them and selecting which genes they want. For example most companies don't care if their GMO is less nutritious or less healthy (both of which aren't poisonous or detrimental for your health, so they'll be passed and allowed) but obviously that is not a positive change for us. Most of these companies only care about maximizing profits, so if they can make the plant grow more and kill insects they'll choose that even if changing this information has adverse affects on how healthy or nutritious the plant is for consumption. All they want to do is mass produce for as cheap as possible and sell. Extremely cheap highly processed foods are loaded with GMOs for a reason, GMOs could = healthier foods, & more effective farming or it could = less healthy foods but more effective farming. These companies aren't going to put as much work into the former only the latter because they bank on how ignorant a consumer is. I've never been against genetic modification, but I will admit that I strayed too far into the "non-gmo" concept. The non-gmo initiative is inherently positive though: it aims for greater transparency about how the fuel for our bodies is produced; it promotes ecologically friendly methods of agriculture; and it combats reckless, monopolistic corps like Monsanto and Bayer. I'm a PhD graduate in chemistry and I really appreciated this video because it is 100% valid and correct. The thing is, GMOs would only be great in a perfect world. Guess what, it's not.
It actually raises many issues that aren't mentioned in this video (for lack of time or resources, I'm sure)
First, farmers have to purchase seeds each year from big corporations (e.g. Monsanto). Even if they had the capacity and infrastructures to save their own (which is a hassle), they wouldn't be 100% sure they'd get the same plants. Also Monsanto often sues farmers who save their seeds because it patents many of the varieties it develops.
Secondly, many farmers report insects and "superweeds" that have developed resistance to glyphosate, hence increasing the use of chemical pesticides. Now farmers have to rely on a suite of chemicals for weed and pest control (not as much as in conventional intensive farming, but again: Monsanto).
And finally, in developing countries, the golden rice outcome isn't that conclusive: farmers in SE Asia gave contrasting reports, and many of small farmers raised concerns about the costs to maintaining GMO crops hence relying on larger corporations, if not being overtaken by them altogether. That simply doesn't help local communities.
Now a personal opinion (not a fact): I simply don't think intensive farming is the answer, periodt.

2:14 For the record, many farmers tend to prefer terminator crops.

Think back to high school biology when you learned about dominant and recessive genes. Specifically, think of the pink rose example. A red rose plus a white rose will always produce the seeds for a pink rose. Breeding two pink roses, however, will produce 25% red seeds, 25% white seeds, and 50% pink seeds but you can't tell which is which until you plant them.

Most farmers who have this knowledge of botany (i.e. the overwhelming majority of crop farmers) would prefer the consistency of buying new seeds each planting instead of only having a fraction of their crop with those desirable traits.

I'm against genetically modified food, because first of all, we don't even know the long-term effects. I have a bunch of reasons and if y'all did research you would probably be worried too.
Health concerns:
-Toxic effects (hepatic [liver], pancreatic [pancreas], renal [kidneys], or reproductive): each insertion of a gene is random, GE food producers don't know where their gene is being inserted because they don't completely know the makeup of the food; they can't establish a "safe" place to insert it, so such food companies just hope that the new genetic material does not destabilize the food and make it hazardous. Each genetic insertion creates the added possibility that formerly nontoxic elements in the food could become toxic.
-New allergic reactions: allergies can be transfered from one food to another. If you are allergic to nuts but not soybean, and they are take DNA from a nut aand insert it into soybeans, now you are allergic to these genetically modified soybeans that are beginning to take over organic soybeans.
-They use growth hormones, which have been shown to increase IGF-1, which promotes the possiblity of developing cancer.
-Loss of nutrition: by modifying the aliment, they alter the nutritional value of it.
-Antibiotic resistance: they could make disease-causing bacteria resistant to current antibiotics, resulting in a significant increase in the spread of infections and diseases in the human population.
-Farmers aren't forced by the U.S. Food & Drug Administration to label genetically modified food, so people eat it without knowing.
-Many companies never subject their genetically modified foods to mandatory government testing of any sort.
-Tests indicate there are harmful effects on organ development, body metabolism, and immune function.
Edit: for those asking for proof, this is a comment section so all the studies can’t be fitted here, just go to the internet and do research on why GMOs are bad. There are countless articles, scientific texts, and studies.

As a horticulturist who has studied and used GMO seed, sprayed chemical fertilizers and pesticides, I can tell you that the main issue isn't biology or the environment.

To be fair, farmers who do round-up ready corn or soy, for example, are hard-working and passionate about their businesses. The problem is most of them have been conned into a cycle of purchasing round-up ready seed, fertilizer and pesticides from a handful of companies and use the soil as a SUBSTRATE instead of amending it properly to increase soil structure and OM content. They do this because the fertilizers that they use bind to other elements in the ground and are sifted out when it rains. Match that with compaction from the tractors that have to pass in the fields and the law of increasing demand for fertilizer and you have yourself a perfect recipe for disaster.

On the other hand, there have been discoveries in recent years like when they discovered the bacteria Bascillus Thurigiensis as an effective control for many pest problems, which really shows the power of good science for the economy and the environment. BT is cheap to make, has an ultra-low/non-existant toxicity for most applications and is more effective than older chemical pesticides for its designated uses.

With drones and better technology for precision agriculture, we can make the transition towards a better agricultural industry that meeds the demand for global food, that is financially sustainable for the farmer and that is environmentally sustainable for our future. GMO's are a fascinating technology, but it needs time and can't be rushed. There's a lot we can do now!

In an ideal world, like the FAO recommends, we would be farming on much smaller pieces of land much more intensely, but that just simply is not possible with the current labour shortage we have now. It's really hard to convince people to take up a career as a farmer, especially if they are from the city.

As a row-crop producer in the United States, I greatly appreciate your objectivity on this topic. The opposition to GM crops often paint farmers as deliberate abusers of the environment and poisoners of the world. In reality, most farmers are honest, hard-working, and intelligent people—often whose family has taken care of the same parcels of land for multiple generations(even centuries). We utilize modern, data-driven technology to attempt to efficiently feed the growing world in a manner that is both safe and effective, ultimately reducing the overall burden of our practices on the natural landscape. We are far from perfect, though. Modern agriculture and its technology has not been without missteps and shortfalls in the last few decades alone; however, we are continuously learning from these mistakes and evolving our management practices to prevent them from being repeated. I do not speak in certainties, and I hope that some day we do not discover more data that shows harm in our current tools. For now, though, it would be irresponsible for us to overlook GM technology based solely on unproven claims, when it can allow farmers to successfully provide for humanity as it continues to grow.

Thank you for coming to my TED talk, and I hope that life brings you all the fulfillment and joy that you deserve.

Carbon sequestering means that trees cannot end climate change caused by carbon dioxide. Anything they pull out of the atmoshpere is released back into it when they die. The carbon is not sequestered semi-permanently, like oil and coal deposits deep under ground. The result is that trees have a zero net impact on carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, and are merely storage vessels for keeping all the carbon from being in the air at one time.

From the evolution point of view, the BT GMO can be very dangerous to the ecosystem. The BT gene is a huge advance for a plant to survive in the natural environment, because the plants carrying this gene is resistant to herbivores. If the BT gene leaked from the GMO crop to its wild relatives, the wild plant species will gain this power to poison insects. And this power will very likely to be fixed by natural selection. If this is fixed in a natural population of a plant species, this gene will be very likely moving to other populations. And this will kill a lot of insects and causing the collapse of the ecosystem by disrupting the food chain. Therefore, in fact, the technology itself is not dangerous. The dangerous thing is how to use it and where to use it. the gene flow of a plant population is one of the hardest things to control, because of the pollen. pollen can be carried away by many media, such as insects and wind. That's why regulations should be applied on the technology. Another issue is the genes used to transform a plant. If the genes used to transform the plant can have interactions with intestine cells, these genes should not be applied for the transformation process. How can they interact? at least, in insect, the digested mRNA of plant tissue eaten by insects can be directly up taken by the cells of the insect guts. These small fragments of mRNA can sometimes interact with the mRNA in the gut cells to initiate RNAi process to silent gene expression in the gut cells of insects. This can be fatal. Therefore, regulations and a lot of researches should be done, before releasing GMO crops and food to the market.

SELECTIVE BREEDING IS NOT AT ALL GOOD

My grandpa (may he rest in peace) "genetically engineered" a watermelon variety through selective breeding over a couple of decades. Sadly, this variety is gone, it died with him. He spent decades saving seeds from the tastiest and sweetest watermelons from his garden. The end result that I got to see and taste for myself was amazing. So juicy, so sweet, and just the right size for one person to eat. I have never before or since tasted such a delicious watermelon. It's a great shame that the only remaining seeds he had vanished like they did. When I was a kid, I thought those watermelons were what was normal. After his passing, I found out quickly that his watermelons were perfection compared to anything else I have tried. I have given up trying to find a suitable replacement. It has been almost twenty years since his passing.

GMO food is going to become non-optional sooner rather than later. As global climate change continues, we will need to start designing our crops to adapt to these very different climates than what we traditionally use. Potatoes that support micro-environments to replenish the soil nutrients they use, watermelons resistant to drought, wheat resistant to flooding, heat resistant broccoli, cold resistant peppers, and so on. As regional climates change, crops traditionally grown in those areas will fail and famine will follow. Our options are to either stop or substantially slow global climate change (which isn't happening any time soon) or develop crops appropriate for these new climates.

One of these things is a lot more likely to happen than the other.

Thinking that humans have enough knowledge of genetics to venture in such modifications completely certain of their effects and consequences is at best foolish. We cant even forsee the consequences of introducing a species in a different ecosystem (see australia among other notable examples). There are negative effects and unforseen consequences to GMO, which vary from negligible nutritional value to intolerance/alergenic properties and even some we can't even imagine. Overconfidence is the precursor to some of the biggest mistakes. There are some points I perceive that were not clarify here, and I want to say that I'm not against GMO's, I think they could be a great tool but, of course, they need a lot of further investigations beyond the knowledge we have nowadays:


1.- What about the microfauna that makes the ground alive and fertile, could GMO's mean a change on that fauna that ultimately cause the dead of the ground where they're planted. There are quite a few examples of cases in which humans touched an element from a natural ecosystem and screwed it all up. Could it be that by eliminating plagues we are altering an ecosystem that is much more important for the health of the ground?


2.- There is a big technical problem. We humans, normally are very bad on predicting things even though we think we are good, and more when it's related to nature, due mainly to ego, pride or emotional problems that interfere between our discovery and our personal issues, in the same way, in century XX we started to define agriculture from the point of view of pure chemistry and thinking that a land is like a Petri dish where we can add ingredients and have plants coming out, which was a total mistake, and now we have the problem of vast sterile lands all over the world due to this horrible.


3.- We know that we don't know a lot of things about nature, and we don't know that we ignore a lot more facts about nature. We know for example that metabolism of cells follows a row of steps which are necessary to transform one element (let's say sun light' photons) into another (let's say energy in form of ATP, in plants), and we know they are necessary to be in the way plants do it, and it's not the same to just introduce Nitrogen or Potasium in the ground as to let cells do it, because inside this long and complex metabolism there are mid steps, that produce mid products that go to other processes and follow their paths, also cells in this way have the possibility to control the speed of the transformation, etc Could it be that GMO's normal metabolism gets altered by changing a part that seemed to be independent from another process taking place inside the plant? Also we have to add to this point that I wouldn't be the first time we are not able to predict the complexity of gens expression.


4.- There is another point about avoiding plagues and other factors that could damage the crops and this is that you don't need a laboratory and any gen modification for that, and I actually thinks it's a bit clumsy (sorry if I offense) to look inside laboratories to find something that we have naturally inside plants, and in the knowledge of how nature does work and the connection created between organism in the ecosystems. That means that we already know that by properly mixing plants and elements with different properties let's say, by imitating the "natural way", not only we don't need any external product to either fertilize or avoid plagues, but we also are contributing to the natural health and productivity of the land, just by choosing where and how to mix the elements of nature, for example mixing plants that avoid plagues, or trees that cover from wind and sun, or plants that give to the floor and the microfauna a healthy chemical reservoir, or using animals manure to enrich the earth, ...


I think, as you proposed, the real aim of agriculture should be to find a more efficient and healthy way to grow food as the same time it keeps a balance with the environment which should be another basic parameter to consider that a crop land is really efficient, and not only how much quantity or money comes in how much comes out.
Maybe we have to find a middle point between new technology and the obvious advantage that it offers and the knowledge about how natures works by its own, so we both get a productive agriculture and healthy food at the same time we regenerate or help maintain the ecosystem which is a crucial point in order to keep thriving as a specie.

Soil depletion. The soils of the earth are depleted of vital minerals. The causes are faulty farming methods, including the use of superphosphate fertilizers and the use of toxic insecticides and pesticides that damage the soil microorganisms.
GMO crops. These are very unsafe because some contain pesticides in their genes that harm the soil and those who handle and eat the crops.
Hybrids designed only for increased yield. These deplete the soil by sending up too many plants per acre. These plants suck up too many minerals, more than can be replaced with any fertilizers.
The result is “soil mining”, meaning the removal of vital minerals from the soil. As this occurs, the soil dies, dust bowls form, erosion increases and the topsoil of the earth blows away in the wind.

As for the claim about studies proving GMOs are as safe as natural crops-
you can't really make that claim. You can claim that previously created GMO crops have been shown to be as safe as natural plants but any day a lab may create some nightmare plant which would of course not be reflected in the data so far.


Here's the issue I keep coming back to. Humanity has literally tens of thousands of years of experience with cross-breeding animals and plants. It's one of our oldest technologies, and yet as recently as the 1970s we screwed up badly creating the so called "killer" bees (Africanized honey bees).



Genetic engineering is vastly more powerful than crossbreeding, and we have a mere 50 years experience. The same people creating the GMOs have economic incentives to lie about their safety and have repeatedly been caught making claims that proved utterly false (like their GMOs being unable to cross-contaminate natural crops, which has been shown to have happened time and again).



So why would we possibly believe these people have the knowledge and integrity to wield this kind of power?


Ecologies are chaotic systems and there is no more dramatic a change to make to an ecology than the introduction or elimination of one or more species. We simply cannot predict how these GMOs will behave in the wild and how the wild will change in response. Lab trials are fine, but releasing them with such little care into the world is practically suicidal.

This video was doing a perfectly good job until the 5:00 mark, then it adopts a thoroughly Luddite, anti-science perspective.


What is the video saying the problem is? The agriculture industry has developed plants which are resilient to glyphosate. Because of its ability to safely control for pests, it has become adopted by many farmers. The video then claims that this is bad, not because of any demonstrable negative consequences to human health, but because it's not egalitarian. In effect, a better world would be one where the inferior farming practices of Luddites and anti-science cranks ought to be given equal consideration. It's like saying that we ought to give equal consideration to the hand loom because the advent of the textile mill made it obsolete.


In addition, nobody is forced to use glyphosate or any GMO crop. People choose to do so because of the practical economic advantages it offers which they have judged themselves. It results in greater yields and lower costs for the agriculture industry, and lower costs and selection for consumers. If somebody else claims they can do it better, they are free to offer a better alternative - if they can.

After reading some of the sources provided by this video, it seems that this video makes some claims that the sources do not support. At the very least to say "The science is in. Eating GMO plants is no more risky than their non-GMO equivalent" (quote from the video) is not supported by the provided sources.


Here are some examples:


In regards to the source labeled "# Are GMOs bad for your health."
-This article is is not about human health. It is about the effect of Genetically Engineered plants on the biodiversity of plants in general. It does not really mention humans.


In regards to the source labeled : "GMOs are safe– various studies and reports by respected authorities: National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine."
-First I would it should be noted that this is not a study conducted on GE crops it is a review by a collection of experts and committees of experts about the relevant studies that have already been conducted.
-In Chapter 5 "Human Health Effects of Genetically Engineered Crops"
--In the introduction to this chapter the study states:
"It is important to make clear that there are limits to what can be known about the health effects of any food, whether non-GE or GE. If the question asked is "is it likely that eating this food today will make me sick tomorrow"? researchers have methods of getting quantitative answers. However, if the question is "is it likely that eating this food for many years will make me live one or a few years less than if I never eat it?" the answer will be much less definitive. Researchers can provide probabilistic predictions that are based on the available information about the chemical composition of the food, epidemiological data, genetic variability across populations, and studies conducted with animals, but absolute answers are rarely available."
--Also in the introduction the study states:
"With regard to the issue of uncertainty, it is useful to note that many of the favorable institutional statements about safety of foods from GE crops in Box 5-1 contain caveats, for example: “no overt consequences,” “no effects on human health have been shown,” “are not per se more risky,” and “are not likely to present risks for human health.” Scientific research can answer many questions, but absolute safety of eating specific foods and the safety of other human activities is uncertain."
--Also in this chapter, in the section OVERVIEW OF U.S. REGULATORY TESTING OF RISKS TO HUMAN HEALTH
"FINDING: The current animal-testing protocols based on OECD guidelines for the testing of chemicals use small samples and have limited statistical power; therefore, they may not detect existing differences between GE and non-GE crops or may produce statistically significant results that are not biologically meaningful."


"FINDING: In addition to experimental data, long-term data on the health and feed-conversion efficiency of livestock that span a period before and after introduction of GE crops show no adverse effects on these measures associated with introduction of GE feed. Such data test for correlations that are relevant to assessment of human health effects, but they do not examine cause and effect."


"RECOMMENDATION: Before an animal test is conducted, it is important to justify the size of a difference between treatments in each measurement that will be considered biologically relevant."


"RECOMMENDATION: A power analysis for each characteristic based on standard deviations in treatments in previous tests with the animal species should be done whenever possible to increase the probability of detecting differences that would be considered biologically relevant."


"RECOMMENDATION: In cases in which early published studies produced equivocal results regarding health effects of a GE crop, followup experimentation using trusted research protocols, personnel, and publication outlets should be used to decrease uncertainty and increase the legitimacy of regulatory decisions."


"RECOMMENDATION: Public funding in the United States should be provided for independent follow-up studies when equivocal results are found in reasonably designed initial or preliminary experimental tests."

The biggest problem with plants producing their own pesticides is tolerance. We're already starting to see its effects in cotton (a very popular BT crop that is in it's third incarnation last time I looked). Unlike viruses which can be stopped by a single transformation (like a vaccine) herbicides and pesticides just contribute to the arms race that is nature. Produce a better pesticide, produce a better pest. We really need to find a pest and weed management system that rotates to prevent tolerances from building so quickly.
We also haven't really been able to produce a food I'm aware of where the touted benefits actually show through (that beta-karotine rice produced a form unusable to humans). I'm hopeful for the future of GMO but we really need to get it into the hands of freelance scientists or agricultural scientists and other innovators. As long as its in the hands of people who profit off pesticide, we'll see about as much innovation in GMOs as we have in renewable energy from oil companies.

One thing though, I would like to see the Abbreviations for this controversy changed, so maybe part of the argument can be put to rest.  It is my understanding that a GMO occurs naturally, not just by human intervention, like two strains of plants, one being slightly more resistant to a dung beetle or some insect that lives in it's area and likes to eat it's roots.  By natural selection (I think that's what you'd call it) the one plant more resistant to the dung beetle, maybe by having a less tasty root, prevails more often, therefore it's seeds are more successful and grow larger, making more of that strain, and so on and so on.  From what I understand, that is Genetic Modification.  When a farmer from the 1700's or a modern scientist purposely mix two seeds from different strains, or changes an amino acid in a plant seed, to speed up natural selection, or by bass it all together, creating a specifically desired outcome,  would be what I consider Genetic Engineering or GEO.  Or is the farmer that is just combining seeds hoping for a better result, still just GMO, and it doesn't reach GEO until scientists change things on a molecular level?  My post is more of a question than statement, what do you all think?

I'm not fully against GMO stuff, but thanks to being semi-scientifically illiterate (especially in this department) always wonder about the unintended side effects of GMOs. Especially when the GMO research is done by profit-seeking companies. Seeking profit is not inherently bad, it funds the research for a better product and reimburses the effort put into the research. The problem comes when companies say it's "safe" when the real answer is "Uh... we don't really know yet... But we believe it's safe, so you should too!" without actually researching about the impact. Even if they actually went to double check and found out it's "unsafe", they might keep mum because "It concerns profit, and Lawsuits" or for the involved workers "I'll lose my job if they found out I'm the whistleblower". Humans have a tendency to ignore unpleasant truth, even if it endangers them (or others), and with incentives (PROFIT! NOT GETTING SUED!) they're even more likely to do so. I'm not sold on the idea that "they say it's safe, so it must be safe". There are PLENTY of loopholes in the law and experiment techniques that they WILL find and use (I.e. cherry picking the data, etc).

Many companies had this checkered past, especially old chemical companies that invent chemicals for whatever purposes, say it's "safe" when they sell it, then went back to the lab for double check. They found out some of their most popular product isn't as harmless as they claim to be, but keep mum about it because it concerns PROFITS! Yeah, fuck 'em! My worries about GMO is similar to this. If GMO producing companies keep mum when health organizations missed some unwelcome side effects that they knew about because it concerns profits, we're fucked (at least those that consumes their product).

The issue with GMO crops is not danger associated with eating the crop. The danger is that GMO crops are completely controlled by agro-giant Bayer, and only work when sprayed with additional pesticides, herbicides, and fungicides which are sold to farmers by Bayer alongside the GMO seeds. The GM seeds are contracted to farmers for 1 year cycles, so farmers aren't allowed to save seeds or they face legal charges. This means they have to keep buying new seeds from Bayer. The brute forth growth of plants allowed by GMO genes, and the toxic chemicals doing the job the GM plant's failing immune system can't do anymore, kills all the important life and soil and causes soils to die off over time. Crops are only as nutritious as the soil they are grown in. We are now at a point where GMO farms have such nutrient devoid soils, that GM crops often only contain 5% of certain nutrients that an organic version of that crop would contain. The pharma giant Bayer has the majority of the USA in a headlock in this way; most GM farmers soils are in such a bad state that without a complete shift to regenerative organic agriculture, they get reliant on Bayer's GM seeds and chemicals just to grow anything at all.

As usual meaningful and well done! But there is a point which could have been mentioned: we do not master genetic modifications yet. We don't know all. We know GMO are safe because we tried. The mapping gene-feature is not 1:1, it is N:N; since we do not know it completely, we go by trial and error. This means that until now tested GMOs were safe, but can't guarantee it for every GMO!

Also, crossing species is not the same thing as GM. To all software engineers out there: crossing species is linking to a different library version, GM is hand-crafting one tiny piece of assembly. Not the same thing at all. I am not arguing against GMO with this, but in a balanced and complete explanation this "detail" shouldn't definitely be skipped.

Genetic modification through selective breeding is a much more slow and natural process. Directly modifying a gene is instant, and it is also prone to an immense number of unknown effects in combination with other genes. All the corporate seed companies combined comprise less than 20% of our global seed supply. As someone who has worked in and studied genetics and related fields...

The whole "Are GMOs safe or not?" debate is dumb. Like, really dumb.

Let me present you a similar dumb question that's dumb for the same reasons....

"Are governments safe or not?"

Hopefully that makes it clear. If not, I will explain.

GMOs take alot of resources to make (like a government), many powerful people have the ability to impact their creation (like a government), it grants a strong level of control to something by the people controlling the process (like a government), is generally not available to those with a normal pocket book (like a government), can be used for horrible things (like creating Military grade Anthrax or ... well... military grade anthrax), or can be used for something that makes our lives all better (like government funded healthcare or super-nutritious corn), it's also possible to make horrible mistakes (like a government ruining a water supply or killing bees due to crop engineered to kill insects.... like polinating bees).

Saying all GMOs are good or bad would be like saying all governments are good or bad. Some companies are responsible with their process, others (*cough*Monsanto*cough*) care only about their bottom line and are not responsible in their pursuit of cash and lets not go into detail about military applications.

GE crops and foods derived from them are tested in three ways [in-house, pre-marketing, producer tests] : animal testing, compositional analysis, and aller-genicity testing and prediction. Although the design and analysis of many animal-feeding studies were not optimal [note zero reference to human testing] , the many available animal experimental studies taken together provided reasonable evidence [short-term animal evidence only] that animals were not harmed by eating foods derived from GE crops. Data on the nutrient and chemical composition of a GE plant compared to a similar non-GE variety of the crop some-times show statistically signiﬁcant differences in nutrient and chemical composition [per Codex this should trigger Human Testing] , but the differences have been considered to fall within the range of naturally occurring variation found in currently available non-GE crops. Many people are concerned that GE food consumption may lead to higher incidence of speciﬁc health problems including cancer, obesity, gastrointestinal tract illnesses, kidney disease, and disorders such as autism spectrum and allergies. In the absence of long-term, case-controlled studies to examine some hypotheses [no human data, no firm safety hypthesis] , the committee examined epidemiological datasets over time from the United States and Canada, where GE food has been consumed since the late 1990s, .........."

My anti GMO argument is how these plants interact with the wild, pollinators, and pests. Pests will likely adapt to try and win, in the process causing non GMO plants and animals to GO EXTINCT. The old style of GMO(breeding) was slow, and the wild plants and animals were not overwhelmed by "superbugs" because they could keep up. Breeding worked at the same pace as normal evolution. The current and new genetic manipulation is RAPID, and because of this nature won't be able to keep up. And this could cause permanent damage to earths ecosystem. Lets say a bug that lives tree leaves. A GMO fruit tree is rolled out in California, which is incredibly resistant to this "leaf mite". Over a few decades the leaf mites in the state try to adapt to find ways to crack the cell walls of the GMO tree. By the time the new super leaf mite finds a way around the fruit tree's defenses it has become nearly unstoppable and is mingling with other varieties. A century later, Deciduous trees are nearly extinct in the western world because the over evolved mites tear through them in a matter of months. The dead forests(much like pine beetle damaged pines), become an extreme fire hazard and Co2 factory

ALL PATENTS EXPIRE after 20 years. GMO soybeans are generic and cheap now, a bargain for farmers. FARMERS DO NOT WANT TO REPLANT HYBRID SEEDS!!! If you save seed do not buy patented seed to do so. A first grade child can understand that. There are many companies even foreign companies producing and selling GMO technology seed. Okay, so I have been studying this topic for many many many hours now. And while I agree that GMOs are not always bad, I absolutely do not believe that modifying a plant to be resistant to herbicides such as glyphosate means that it is safe for human consumption. Herbicides and pesticides are toxic and the long-term effects of their consumption have yet to be studied in depth. My only advice to farmers looking at growing GMO crops is "proceed with caution." These are things that cannot be undone once all of the wild genes are bred out of a crop. It is irreversible and its applications may not always be for the good of humanity.

I think you hit the nail on the head when you said it is was like intensive farming. Intensive farming methods are causing long term damage to our land. Build up of salts, damaging of the soil ecosystem, need for excessive amounts of water etc.

I also do not think it is helpful to discuss GMOs are one monolithic entity. i.e. tomatoes modified using antisense genes to reduce ripening times, should not be judged alongside tomatoes modified to resist herbicides.

Also the arguments about safety presented in the research have one major flaw. They assume that illnesses caused by GMOs will be apparent as being caused by GMOs. This is not to say there is data to show that GMOs are causing negative side effects, but to illustrate how difficult this debate is. Medicine for example is monitored by specialists i.e. your Doctor. If it causes a side effect it is more likely to be detected as the cause by the specialist. Most people eating GMOs are not specialists. Also most people do not know that they are eating GMOs, so even if they were specialists they would not know if a GMO caused the symptom or not. In the US GMOs are not labelled and this is true for most countries that allow them.

You rightly identified the economic issue as a major concern, but not really elaborated on this as much as I think you should. Concerns about patent is a major issue. Varieties bred by communities for thousands of generations, can be taken by a company, modified slightly and then patented, without any compensation to the community that originally bred in thousands of other beneficial traits. Nor did you address the fact that GM companies have successfully sued farmers whos crops have been contaminated with GM. Not only have these farmers lost in many cases their status as non GM but now have to pay license fee, for a product they never wanted, but was introduced by seeds being dispersed. One famous case in Canada, where a truck with GM seeds crashed and those seeds contaminated his land where he grew plants he bred over decades, went bankrupt because of the dispute.

You failed to discuss how farmers in India that initially bought the new BT toxin resistant cotton, saw a dramatic drop in yield of 17%, which led to large numbers of suicides, as farmers had borrowed money on the promise that it would increase yield, when really the small print always says "COULD". Reality was they were sold BT cotton designed for the US and not tested in India. There is clearly huge scope for abuse in the system.

There are some clear success cases for GMOs i.e. Hawaiian papaya (although not all of the papaya is GMO, so one wonders if natural selection would have done its business and we would have a GMO free papaya industry). However, my pet hate is the golden rice example. People are still using this as a future possible solution to a problem that has nothing to do with nutritional content with food. There is enough food on this planet to feed an additional two billion people even now. The solution is not GMOs, as the price of food is often controlled by governments and indeed by companies that profit from it. The problem is distribution.

The pretense that GMOs are offering a solution to this problem is laughable. It is not the solution to world hunger, not even close. It is not even the solution to drought resistance, in many cases as is often spouted. Intensive farming and in some cases even traditional farming has destroyed the land. Other more sustainable solutions have been tested (TED talks has a great video on one of these, but dont have the link to hand) and exist. Did you know that the record for rice production is held by a farmer in Bihar, that used a simple method of not doing intensive farming and basically spaced out his crop more (bit more complicated than that, but basically), literally quadrupled his yield. BBC report on it somewhere.

I could go on, but you get the point. It is not cut and dry.

GMO's aren't inherently bad, but the way corporations grow them is. For example, Monsanto has a type of corn that is made to grow with an herbicide. The fields are soaked in this herbicide, and only their corn grows. This causes all of the guys in the area to go away and so Monsanto requires that their farmers plant a 10% portion of organic crops so the bugs stay, and Monsanto will sue farmers (who are paying customers) who fail to do this. This is also one of the things that harms bees. Also, terminator seeds are used in India, and indian farmers have killed them selves because they did not make a big enough profit to buy seeds again. Also, GMO food is not made to feed the world, it is made for profit. 40% of corn is for ethanol, another 36% for livestock feed. This leaves 34% to actually be eaten, and then that 34% is either exported or turned into high fructose corn syrup. Also, glyphosate is very bad for the microbiome (something kurzgesagt made a video on) and the intestinal wall. So just because it doesn't directly kill us, doesn't mean it can't harm you in other ways. Also, vertical farming can solve the hunger problem without genetic modification or any kind of _____icide once elon musk makes solar panels cheap.

Now, imagine this:
Hydroponics, or aeroponics + gmo + modern machinery
Vs
Soil growing + organic + some guys payed to gather the veggies.

Which is the true ecological solution? The first one of course. It needs less water, less nutrients, less pesticides, and less energy (biochemical energy of the food feeding the men vs mechanical energy that can and will be obtained from renewable resources), and could potentially have more yield. So, i get it, you may like the picture of the old man with a scythe harvesting the wheat, that's nice, but think, and ask to an old farmer, how much pesticides did he used? If not, how much crop did he lost? How many liters of kerosene did his tractor consumed? True, the human population were less conspicuous, but imagine that technique applied to the present world. It may mean starvation for the 90% people not in the top step of the economy pyramid, and I don't want to live in a world where people starve cause of nice landscaping. Bear in mind, neither I want to live in a world overpopulated, and reducing the population would help.

I think GMOs should have stricter patent conditions, for example, if the genetically modified organism is modified only for fashion (Ex: GloFish), or sterile GMO, it may be patented, but if it's for practical purposes (Ex: AquAdvantage, Monsanto corns), it shouldn't, because if the genes spread to other plants, they can patent every single organism in the world. It also creates other conflicts, what if a GM organism has genes of two different companies (Ex: a corn has Monsanto and Syngenta genes). It's better for fertile GMOs to be owned by state and unpatentable.

When humans eat BT crops, like corn, the BT's aggressive mechanisms attack normal and healthy gut cells, which can leave holes in your intestines. Even worse, the BT doesn't leave you body for weeks, or even months.

For me the part of GMO that makes me cautious is that I don't trust that we currently understand the systemic impacts of our modifications (by systems I mean the human body as well as ecosystems).

In the past, genetic modification took place over long periods of time. Now we could reasonably replace most of the corn grown in a country with a new strand in a matter of years. I worry that our ability to move so quickly might lead to us over-committing on a GMO with consequences that won't be seen until it is applied at scale.

I completely believe that GMO is the way to go, but we need better ways to examine the impact of specific GMOs on complex systems , or at least a better way to increase confidence in specific GMOs from someone like myself.

Actually a critique of GMOs regarding contemporary agricultural practices is also still very valid critiques of GMOs, because this is how they are actually used and what they are developed for, irl. The argument made in this video is the same as saying that nuclear bombs aren't the problem, it's how we use them (deflecting asteroids vs war, eg). I mean let's be honest here, I'm sure you've more than a few scientists trying to save the world from starvation and they have fantastic ideas, but they are used as tools in a larger corporate game that they are generally fairly oblivious about, blinded by their private sector pay, silenced with confidentiality agreements, incapable of controlling even their own publishing activity (various companys like monsanto have forced publications and stopped the release of others bearing negative results, citing editorial rights in contracts with scientists and there has yet to be reform on this issue in some places). Surely science, even corporately, is far less shady than many alternatives, but that's not the point here. Are GMOs bad for your health? The answer, on average is yes: they cause poverty, replace traditional farming practices which might be more sustainable, decrease genetic diversity (ask the banana about that one), have fed the winged pollinator collapse; all of which have negative impacts on, ultimately, our health.

Just because we can/do make GMOs, does not instantly mean we get all the benefits out of them that every graduate promises at the very end of their mostly irrelevant doctoral theses.

Wouldn't it be great if you could just sue your competition out of business? What GMOs actually are is a strategy to achieve total control of the food supply. Just think for a second, what happens when there are no more wild plants?

This doesn't just stop at plants, GM animals are owned just like GM plants. So what happens when someone makes a super breed of animal and releases it into the wild. It would easily out compete its wild counterpart, just like an invasive species, forcing it to extinction, and once that happens an entire species is now privately owned. you cannot catch it, eat it, or sell it, unless of course you pay tribute to your overlords. I know this sound a little ridiculous but its the unfortunate reality that we are headed towards.

People need to wake up and face this evil now, otherwise our children and grandchildren will have to face it. At least today we have a choice, we can choose to eat non GMO. Future generations may not have that choice.

Kinda neglecting the political and economic problems. Bangladesh is a particularly bad example, as reportedly, hundreds of thousands of farmers are committing suicide, often burning themselves alive, as a political statement against Monsanto, as the company's aggressively dubious business practices are often driving them into destitution. Monsanto's own stated goal is to control the entire world's agriculture, and having the entire world's food supply under the umbrella of a single corporation is a frightening thought indeed. See also the documentaries "Bitter Seeds" as well as some others available here on Youtube.

I agree that GMOs are going to be a requirement for humanity's continued survival - even if we somehow capped the population where it is now, there current agricultural model and output is unsustainable. Converting everything to "organic farming" isn't a real option, as the death toll from the increased food prices would make the environmental damage the traditional methods cause look like a cakewalk. However, the laws and regulations revolving around GMOs now are focused on maximizing exploitation and profit, not increasing the food supply.

Given that genetic engineering is eventually going to apply to humans themselves (and to some degree, already does), the simplest solution to this is to make patenting genes illegal, via global trade agreement. If we don't do this soon, we're going to have patented people walking about in the near future - generations of them. Making genes unpatentable, eliminates a great deal of the detrimental and exploitive practice companies like Monsanto practice, and would largely mitigate not only the damage they cause, but the power they acru (often used to taint the results of the very GMO safety you are claiming, if you follow some of the stories revolving around your evaluation links).

Some would argue that this would stifle genetic research, but the nice thing about new gene formulae, is you only need to create them once. Further, you'd still be able to patent gene research methods, and sell that service - not to mention the government could always fund such. The potential for increased crop yields is more than enough profit motive, in and of itself. At the same time, you would have no legal justification to lay claim to someone's farmland, simply because your patented genes cross-pollinated with their crops, and other such dirty practices that ruin many lives, for the profit of a few.

The video doesn't mention the other way humans modified organisms before genetic engineering. Many of our food plants are the result of this process. The process is called Mutation breeding. What was done was small grafts of a plant were exposed to radiation or chemicals that caused them to mutate. Those that survived were grown into full grown plants and any traits that were deemed desirable we're bread into the main food line source. Unfortunately there are also many other traits that were randomly created at the same time with random effects that were bred into the plants too. That means that some of the plants you eat today have unintended unknown genetic mutations caused by radiation. Does this sound safer than selectively adding a desired trait to a plant through genetic modification?
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_breeding

We don't need any source of food modified to hold pesticides and herbicides that are inherently bad (The argument that it being "just a little harmful xddd" is silly.) for our body by companion planting and Permaculture techniques, GMO crops harm the top soil that we're already ruining via tilling, and our ignorant view on soil as a pure growing medium instead of understanding the microbiological make up of healthy soil (Or biodiverse as you might find being sold as a premium for their unequivocal boons for growing, nitrates, vitamins, and all.). There are farms in Canada doing the same, one known as the "Miracle farm" ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3riW_yiCN5E ) has found that planting in a variety hindered the spread and actions of pests as they were weakened and would become exhausted to jump to more than one variety of say, a fruit tree. (The miracle farm spaced varietals in the hundreds every 5 or so feet, tight knit. and many would often grow grapes to then hang off and help shade the area and took up grow space that could be used by more opportunistic plants, like the weeds that we find so much of an issue.)


This has never really been an issue of science, the fact that people think they can explain to another that their "Pest shield 9000" is actually and quite reasonably something that people feel the need to avoid considering the nature of pesticides and herbicides, especially considering the Swiss' toxicology tests on a conventional/GMO diet versus an organic one, and other such as https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2952409/ and continuing.

Ignore the rhetoric of company and extremists alike, and understand that the only thing we had to do was revolutionize, and in the terms of proper and superior Permaculture farming and soil revitalization techniques, all we had to do was out art the problems; and all of this was achieved simply by observing nature, and operating humbly, and artistically within those bounds, from that all problems of pests, weeds, and water can be fixed just as efficiently as any other method, it's all about design, the flat cubic blocks of standard and dross ideals of what truly is valuable and cost effective, and what quality really means.

This is coming from someone that's spent time in both fields, from working with Monsanto corn in Iowa where we regretfully grow mostly for ethanol instead of any source of food, and still ignore the dwindling growable soil in the world, to small 4h groups through Florida, and gardner groups in Colorado working with Permaculture, Huggleculture, water retention landscapes, generic companion planting, and more advanced methods of quality and quantity systems of growing such as Aquaponics.

All of these methods I suggest all that have not a true inkling to agriculture, it's history, and the methodologies that have been passed down, lost, and are slowly now coming more into being; you would do yourself a great honor by even partaking in (plain, traditional) Organic, Monoculture, Permaculture, and aquaponics farms via groups like the WWOOFing network, as in exchange for time and effort, and perhaps lessons if you have a skill or trade you are passionate in (Many families that house WWOOFers love art, music, and the richness of the world. Imparting that on a family or a hard working group is a kind and noble act.) you can also share your worldly excitement.

To separate people who are against this particular form of Genetic modification (Including chemicals for defense of simple agricultural issues.), from those that are "Smart, educated, and 'scientific'." is petty ad-hom BS. This all boils down to people wanting maximize their profits, with no regards to quality. Which in itself is NOT materialist, but is consumerist.

So with that note, work with the Earth which we strive and encourage others to take care of, see if these methods work for you! Because there is no doubt in my mind that you'll find that an apple orchard in your property filled with the finest, most piquant fruits and nutrient dense vegetables is something people work their whole lives to achieve, wealth of the land.

A couple things:
-I think GMO is the future whether we like it or not - we never stop progress
-We'll never know how changes in food will affect our biochemistry in processes we don't understand (including difficult to predict hypersensitivity reactions) - we can't even do that w/ "natural" food
-Business practices don't just effect company dependence (pesticide-ready crops). Business doesn't just want to increase yields and save Bangladesh & Hawai'i, they also want something that will sell - fruits with higher sugar content with lower nutrient diversity as an example; I see little reason why business's effect on how food is prepared won't also translate into the changes in how food is structured: attractive>healthy.
-American copyright laws favor businesses in rights to proprietary genetics; as these proprietary genetics "wander" and pollinate "normal" (open-source?) DNA, independent producers have lost rights to their crops because they were infected with protected proprietary DNA; there have been accusations that these infections were intentional (Monsanto issues), however, I don't believe that matters, eventually mingling of DNA will happen in any case. GMOs themselves aren't a concern at all. It is what they are used for.

They likely aren't that big a health concern. At the very most they use factory farming which creates a less nutritious food product, and are generally varieties that are used in unhealthy overprocessed food. They are tailored to these foods thus reducing the prices of them and increasing the prices of other healthier foods.

The bigger question is if they are bad for the environment.

More specifically if what the current GMOs are being designed factory farming.

While the jury is still out, several of the practices of factory farming, such as chemical burn-down, chemical only fertilizer, mono-culture and deep tilled fields with straight narrow rows can be detrimental to the environment. It is notable that these techniques are used without GMOs as well, and are bad with or without them. GMOs might actually make the processes less destructive by allowing use of less chemicals while using these methods. However, they are still enabling these methods.

While I do understand the positive points of GMOs, the negative impact of them can't be understated.

The negative point presented in the video is actually the biggest issue I take with GMOs. They essentially serve as a bandage to further enable us to become more comfortable and overly dependent on an unsustainable system. Soil nutrient density is decreasing and salinity is increasing rapidly from over-farming plots of land. Soil came about as a result of millions of years of geological activity, and it isn't something we can so easily replace.

GMOs give us the ability to teach plants to grow bigger and more colorful with higher soil salinity, and less nutrients, which as a temporary fix is great, but if the underlying issues remain unchecked... it will kill us all after some time.

In addition, each modification to a plant could present harmful effects to not only human bodies, but the entire ecosystem. Studying any one change and fully understanding its effects at large, could take more than decades of repeated research. It simply isn't enough to just blanket study one set of modifications and then say "Okay! GMO's are 100% safe and always will be!".

I do agree, GMOs can be used well, but currently they aren't being used too help humanity. They're being used to extract as much profit as possible from the earth in a reckless manner. The companies lobbying for their unchecked usage right now, certainly do NOT have the community's best interest at heart.

I'll say, I haven't done nearly as much research as these guys have with their 600+ hour video here. But this is a topic that I feel deeply invested in, and is one I studied a bit more closely in college Anthropology. As with a lot of topics, the truth really does lie somewhere between.

Okay, so what I got out of this video is that most GMO's today are not safe as most rely on toxins like roundup;however, some of them are okay because the BT bacteria designed crops produce their own pesticides that are apparently not harmful to humans. Despite all this the potential for good GMO is there, but has not been realized yet. So then why are people saying GMO is safe today, when we havent reached that point yet? Maybe they will be completely safe one day, and maybe not. The risk we have in the future is less biodiversity, and greater chance for a newly undiscovered pest/blight that could potentially wipe out the few strands of GMO crops we may have(Due do survival of the fittest as we perceived at the time, and chose to keep these stronger crops). Keeping just a few good varieties may be our downfall as things change all the time, and new stronger pests are hatched due to survival of the fittest pest.

All of this is also causing waste from animal products production to get into our oceans causing deadzones and pollute the water and the fish we eat. Scientists also actually calculated that if we continue eating fish like we do now, the oceans will be empty in 2048. That's in 30 years. And if the oceans die, we die. It's as simple as that. This is a bigger issue than people think, but all environmental organizations ignore this because in the end they're all companies and need donations to make money and keep their business going, and many people won't donate if the companies say that what they love doing on a daily basis is wrong. (Watch Cowspiracy)

Consuming animal products also has a major impact on our health. New science actually shows us that we are naturally herbivores and not omnivores like we've always thought. In consideration to this it's not surprising that the lifespan is actually going down and that 9 out of 10 top causes of death in the UK can be cured and prevented by living on a plant based diet, including cancer, heart disease, stroke, osteoporosis, Alzheimers etc. (Watch Forks over knives and What the health)

It's not surprising at all that people can get upset when they hear these facts, because they want to continue living as they always have. And I was one of those people too. I believed that humans are omnivores that need animal flesh for protein, cow's milk for calcium etc, and my mind was blown away when I found out nothing of that was true. And it's sad that people are this brainwashed, but the industries continue to do this because they don't want to lose money. Half of the money that for example the egg industries make they use to sponsor people so they will tell others "what health benefits" you get for example eating an egg every single day. These industries has a reason to lie, they want to make money. But vegans don't, because there aren't any big vegan industries that are able to support vegans with that much money.

But health and the environment aren't the only reasons some people want to go vegan, it's the animals too. Animals are mistreated in all the industries, and the diary industry is the worst. Watch 'Earthlings' to see what actually happens behind those closed doors. Even if the animal has a good life and even if they would get massages every day and killed in "the most humane way possible", in the end you're still killing an animal that doesn't want to die. An sentient, kind animal that did nothing wrong, that had family, friends, personality, feelings, and a will to live.

And if you are a meat-eater, I don't blame you. I don't want to be like the vegan stereotype is, angry and judging. But really the most vegans I've met have never been angry or upset, but I totally understand why some people are because the society is so brainwashed and we don't get a chance to let people know the truth. I used to be a meat-eater and I didn't really like vegans and I didn't understand their choice. But now I do. Being vegan is not about being a weird, tree hugging hippies that wouldn't even kill a mosquito. Being vegan is about being compassionate and respectful to all living beings. You don't necessarily have to love animals to be a vegan, but you have to respect them. If someone would be standing and kicking a dog you would probably stop it.
