The top 10 Companies of the GMO Seed market control 67% of the market. Traditionally people would harvest the crops and replant the seeds, but since GMO Seeds can't be replanted you have to buy new seeds from the Supplier every time. This means the seeds always contain the same DNA. There is no genetic diversity within the crops that are grown. Which means it will only take one disease to kill of entire crop fields(nearly all of wheat and soy grown in USA is GMO). Moreover, if we take GMO soy seeds of Monsanto(the highest market share holder in the seed market) they made the plant resistant to their pesticide so it only kills the weeds that grow around the plants. However, this has resulted in some weeds becoming resistant to the pesticide with time(same case of bacteria becoming resistant to antibiotics due to over use). In my opinion GMOs are bad for humanity and the planet.

This video doesn't address important issues : it admits that likely it's impossible to stop gmo characteristics from leaking into the biosphere. The consequence of this is that if at any point we have a regret about a certain gene we have a problem : to turn back the clock you would have to check every seed of every species potentially. Every seed on the planet would have to be checked to ensure that a certain gene that we have regrets about is completely eliminated from the biosphere. In other words it's impossible to turn back. This also means that people who don't want to participate in the GMO adventure don't have a choice : sooner or later their food supply will get "contaminated".

As mentioned earlier in the movie, our selective breeding isn't much different but at least it's governed by the mechanisms (natural selection still plays a role to certain degree, things need to be able to breed, breathe and generally have a baseline of being a real living thing in our physical world) that have generated the current diversity and was more an interaction between nature and humans. In short, nature's mechanisms have a proven track record of yielding a working and varied ecosystem. We have only been meddling for a couple thousand years and genetics is mere decades old. Writing books after thousands of tests checking the things that we know we have to check doesn't and can't prove conclusively that there is no consequence in the long term.

If something can go wrong, it will go wrong sooner or later and that means we could potentially ruin the whole planet. Just because we haven't figured out how yet isn't really an argument to say lets go and do it if the risk is global and irreversible.

Also, things like alligators and sharks have proven so successful they barely changed over millions of years. Currently we humans seemingly expect new releases yearly of everything so maybe our current mindset as a population may be a bit skewed by recent successes such as the writing system followed by printing press followed by internet. Agriculture followed by industry, etc. Yes we seem to be on a roll and going through a transformation. But that doesn't always mean that they old way of doing things was bad or worse. I'm certain you can think of things you have seen changed in the name of progress that were fine or even more pleasant before. In short, not every change is an improvement and it's a common mistake to think it is.

We have changed cows to the point they can't give birth on their own anymore. This would be sad for those cows but no problem if in the rest of the world wild cows could still roam... but I haven't seen a wild cow roaming any plains in over 30 years (* that were not imported from some faraway country where the cows were prettier than our own, i.e. a zoo). You can ser how we humans decide who lives and who dies. If they are not in our service somehow (cute, edible, high yield, ...) we eradicate them. Ugly worms won't be on WWF poster campaigns when they are about to be extinct. People will react "good riddance" as diversity is reduced once again. Humans are not an unbiased force for good and yet we are putting ourselves in charge of the whole planet. We are shaping this planet from our mother into our slave.

I'm not all the way through but I feel you skimmed over the practice of patenting GMO crops; patenting an organism is, by itself, a bit shifty but something that has happened more than once is GM crops contaminating someone's field who did not purchase GM seeds/enter an agreement, resulting in said farmer being sued for "stealing" patented organisms. There's also the dangers of monoculture; a whole field of genetically identical plants, if some un-thought-of disease came through, would be pretty screwed since none would happen to be resistant. Monocultures that do not resist some overlooked or new pest are also prone to pesticide cascades, where stronger and stronger pesticides are required to control the pests, who grow resistant to the pesticide. It's not the GMO crops that are frightening, it's really the entire model of agribusiness, as you mentioned - but I wish you'd gone into more detail, this video seems very propagandist without adequate acknowledgement of counter arguments

You want to start a farm to grow corn. For this farm you want a 20 tonne yield of corn every season. Let's look at two possibile scenarios.
1. With this species of corn you're using you need a hectare of arable land to produce one tonne, so you clear twenty hectares of forest to grow your corn.
2. With this GMO corn species you're using you can produce two tonnes of corn on one hectare because it's been modified for higher yield. So, you deforest 10 hectares to start your farm.

My Grandfather, who has worked with plants for over 50 years now, doesn't think that GMO's are a good idea.

1)Natural selection that farmers did through hundreds of years of breeding is NOT the same as what we are doing now! Anyone who tries to say this is blatantly being dishonest. Name one plant that was bred naturally to contain the venom of scorpions??

2)No company OWNS the crops that were naturally bred for centuries but the rights to GMO crops are owned. Monsanto has already demonstrated that not only does it patent it's crops but worse than that if by no fault of a farmer their crops get cross pollinated then Monsanto has no inhibition suing the innocent farmer.

3)Imagine a future where all our food crops are property of large corporations. They can dictate who grows their crops essentially taking the power to grow our own food out of our hands!! They would literally control the food supply and thereby control the world.

4)Nice try using pesticides as the scapegoat in trying to claim GMO's are our savior. Yes, of course pesticides cause ill health in humans, no one can debate against that! So our solution is to put the pesticide IN the crop!?!? How does this make sense? Oh... certain chemicals are harmful to certain organisms but not others. Like chocolate can kill your dog but perfectly safe for humans? But how are we so sure that bT isn't toxic to humans? We were told Furadan was safe by the scientific community at one point... now it is banned worldwide. Why should we think bT wouldn't be deemed cancerous at some point?

5)As long as the nitrogen fixing and carbon collecting gmo plants do not contain pesticides or scorpion venom which I have to feed my kids then I'm all for it. Until then these arguments and clever narrative isn't going to convince or fool me.

One thing this video very conspicuously fails to mention is seed patenting. Monsanto is one company that modifies the genetic makeup of a seed, like apples, then patents that as a new technology. This could eventually give a corporation ownership of vast swaths of our food supply. I am not anti-corporation nor anti-science, but taking natural resources, modifying them slightly, and then claiming ownership of them as intellectual property is a terrible idea which will likely lead to food monopolies or cartels.

On the scientific side, the possibility of unintended consequences is immense. The biosphere comprises trillions of complex machines interdependent upon trillions of complex machines. Alteration of an entire species may appear benign or innocuous but the impact may not be accurately projected since we cannot account for each layer of the interlocking subsystems within the myriad biological processes. If there were a test Earth, or a computer powerful enough to simulate the results of such alterations we should absolutely proceed. But this is the only earth we have and these chimerical alterations could imperil it.

The problem is, like the video says, that "good GMOs" are only 1% of current GMOs. So indeed most people are fighting the giant manipulative agriculture system, not "GMOs" themselves. But here's the thing: fighting these giant companies is very tough/complicated, because you can't really tell them "what you're doing is wrong". They don't care unless you force them. And forcing them means having something to ban, something which keeps them from carrying out their "evil" business. Well, the easiest way people found was banning GMOs themselves. Is it the GMOs they're fighting? not really. But is it an effective way to discourage agriculture controlled by multinational companies? yes.
Also, a gigantic problem with GMOs not mentioned in the video: be it "good" or "evil" GMOs, they can be protected like a copyright. That's a big point many people are also opposed to: you are copyrighting life, copyrighting species/varieties, which means you can sue somebody for planting seeds of a species/variety which belongs to you.

Natural pesticides inside of nightshades are scary. Glycoalkaloids alpha solanine and alpha chaconine specifically.
“The largest series of solanine poisoning involved an English day school
where 78 schoolboys developed diarrhea and vomiting after eating
potatoes stored since the summer term. Symptoms began 7-19 hours after
ingestion with vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, and malaise. Of the 78
boys, 17 were admitted to the hospital. Other symptoms included fever
(88%), altered mental status (drowsiness, confusion, delirium) (82%), restlessness (47%), headache (29%), and hallucinations (23%).
Three boys were seriously ill with hypotension, tachycardia, and stupor
out of proportion to fluid and electrolyte imbalance. These boys were
discharged 6-11 days after admission, and they had nonspecific symptoms
and visual blurring for several weeks after release from the hospital.”
~Author Barceloux DG, NCBI, 2009.

At first it sounds really nice and convincing. However, I am trained in such a way that you should test every theory with the core foundations. And my problem is that you are saying GMO foods are not sooo bad they are even quite safe and good which by itself is disturbing conclusion. This is in direct contradiction not only with the core foundation that "you should be very careful with things that are easy" in regard to the "easy way" of doing things but also with my senses. Note that I did not use the word "feelings" because as Freud and his nephew Bernays proved feelings can be manipulated with ease (electing Trump is yet another milestone showing just that) and you are continuing to do so quite elegantly as the first comment suggests - very satisfying animation indeed.

Yes, we have come quite far as far as medicine, biology and technology goes, however, let us not fall for the teenage blooming phase trap/paradox. We do not know what are the consequences of eliminating a certain gene, we are quite new to this. The proper response is to take a step back and evaluate our advancement but not a step forward and start profiting of this new knowledge right away. You are playing with fire and you are trying to cover your initial immaturity with even bigger mistakes. However, the other core foundation that I rely on is that "what comes around goes around" so we will inevitably see the ultimate results as we are seeing the disturbingly negative results right now.
I am not saying that soon we will have three arms and a middle leg. What I am saying is that I rely on my core foundations and senses in order to see the transparency of your argument. Just a little example - take a strawberry and look at it. If I take it from the big hipper-mega-tera market in our city I will see tasteless, enormous and hairless fruit. Furthermore, if I take it from the forest the wild strawberry has an aroma, it is melting in your mouth in a flavorful manner, a little bigger than peas and is full with hairs.
What I am trying to say here is that nature "knows" what is the right way and is doing it quite well and for quite some time now. I am trying to understand nature's way (for example with breading strawberry for private use only) and I am just staring. The argumentation does not convince me, as it leaves out a very important point: We cannot know all the consequences it has on the ecosystem. If add a poison for one species that we consider harmful, maybe through a mutation we cannot predict other species would be harmed that are essential for the ecosystem. Maybe a plant that grows too much takes away the space for native plants or takes up too much water or too many nutrients. Maybe animals with certain genetic alterations that would not occur in nature are more likely to get cancer. We just don't know. Maybe there is a reason why evolution has never developed certain abilities.
Comparisons to skepticism towards vaccination are not correct because dead virus shells can no longer harm the body, while a GMO is alive.
When we realize that a species has negative influence, it is already too late. I will just remind you of cane toads in northern Australia that actually live in South America. They were thought to eat certain beetles (yet they do not), but instead they have a drastic effect on biodiversity, with native predators rapidly declining in number.

i agree with the sentiment that gmo's are good, but the modification of plants are immensely more complex than single cell prokaryotes, and other factors like genetic stability (could a potentially harmful version of the plant mutate from the existing gmo's and how could it be protected against, an example might be weather resistant crops and the point at which they become a weed) and resilience from disease - before the invention of gmo's as they are known now the only prevention of harvest destroying diseases was the use of multiple subspecies of a crop being used in one plantation or hybridization of two species, with gmo's from what i understand you get one species that are all genetically the same so disease suavely effect the gmo population, event if the error is easily repaired by the company it is a substantial loss in food produced. finally Monstanto has given gmo's a particularly toxic name by being involved with a series of disputes about cross pollination of their products inspire of their product being infertile (I am aware that plants need to self or cross pollinate in order to produce food, but infertile does come with the subtext that they cannot be impregnated or impregnate other crops with genetically modified produce, the effects of this are huge as pollen can travel a fair distance and regardless of their gmo merit consumers deserve to have their rights respected if they choose non-gmo, that is something that gmo plantations to endanger - this appears to me to be a major screw up on their part ). As a personal opinion i would like to say i don't trust Monsanto and other gmo companies because of their monetary investment in their produce, modification takes a lot of time and money and if there was a potential setback or newer consideration that required a redesign of their product, then they would likely be unable fix it or execute a change it immediately due to the costs associated with it (as likely seen with the cross pollination issues), if company investing in this started genetic modification as a side project and didn't require this to be successful for continued business it then results supporting them would be a fair bit more trustworthy but there is that inheritance bias associated with them and all this could be avoided if a less complex species with shorter life cycles was selected to create a different form of food.

All these arguments are logically sound, but unfortunately, they're probably not going to do much to decrease the opposition towards GMOs when most of the people who oppose them are the same kind of people who think the government is putting poison into vaccines to make their kids autistic. Just saying.

What a nice cute GMO commercial you made here. Unsubscribed.
You failed to address 3 points of valid academic criticism and you focused solely of how great GMOs are.
Here are the points:

1) Horizontal gene transfer between species. Your assertion that GMOs can only crossbreed with their own species has been proven false. Horizontal gene transfer between species has been proven to exist and is a major point of concern as it invalidates all forms of testing currently done on GMOs. The problem being that we only test the substantial equivalency of GMOs to normal variants of the same plant. We have absolutely no idea how the same genes will be expressed in a different plant. Normally only plant DNA gets intermixed with other plants, and that has resulted in the biosphere we know and live in today. However the results of transgenic material from other species being put into plant species for which the sequences were not originally intended by the researchers are not predictable. We might be able to engineer bacteria to suit our own needs basepair by basepair, but even that is not a proven technology yet, and plants are vastly more complex organisms.

2) Biosphere protection. No matter how much you try and protect non-GMO crops from intermingling with GMO crops the fact is that plant species have spread over the entire planet and without them artificially being separated will continue to do so. In other words something that has entered a biosphere is nigh impossible to remove from it. Genetic transfer is much less clean cut than the mendelian reproduction everyone learns in school, or we wouldn't have hundreds of thousands of exogenic elements (mostly from ancient retroviruses) in our very own DNA. One slip up is sufficient and we won't be able to undo it. Your argument about safety is a bit like arguments about the safety of nuclear devices. Not nuclear reactors, because currently a lot of the benefits of GMOs you listed are only hypothetical.

3) GMO research is insufficient. Not only do we not test and can in fact not test the results of a gene being transferred into another species, even the testing done on GMOs themselves is insufficient. Which, by the way, you represented as masses of research all conclusively pointing to one conclusion, even though you had to ignore internal research of the companies that have had many dead-end products that were in fact toxic to humans, which never got released to the wider public and the FDA for testing. As a relative of mine working as a molecular biologist in a company producing GMOs has attested. So GMOs being toxic is not such a theoretical impossibility as you made it seem.
The second point is that all these tests and research papers dealing with GMOs are focused on different varieties, and most just use the testing for substantial equivalency to ascertain that GMO crops are okay for humans to consume. The problem is that there is also some research suggesting that the conformation and the structure of nutrients and substances in food influences how the human digestive tract deals with them. This means that something consisting of completely similar amounts of the same substances could in fact have a different effect on the human body than its counterpart.
The third point here is that all these tests are not independent and unbiased. Firstly reviews found lots of indirect conflicts of interests with these papers, because while the researchers are not on monsanto's payroll, their position and job security would be heavily influenced should their results prove negative things about the GMOs they're testing.
The fourth point is that none of the tests have run continuously for the past 30 years, which they should have been would we want to draw conclusions about the long term effects of substances on humans. Who knows what trace amounts of substances those plants contain that can accumulate to large amounts over the years? We know this about traditionally mutating and growing plants, because it takes a long time of cultivation to produce radically different plants. We do not know this in the case of GMOs.
The fifth point in this category is that unforeseen consequences can occur with any new substance that spreads quickly across the globe. Remember when antibiotics were used universally for all sorts of things even to preempt infections? Some doctors still subscribe to that philosophy. And now look at what's going on today with more superbugs appearing. I am not saying that bugs will evolve to be resistant to pesticides produced by GMO crops, i'm saying that something which initially seems all good can be a problem when overused. And as stated above, once GMOs are in the biosphere you can't really get them out again.
The sixth point is a bit less conventional: As much as laymen would like to believe, the scientific community is not monolithic and logical in all its ways. People leveling criticism against the currently reigning theories and widespread beliefs are laughed out of the park by their colleagues. Therefore accepting something as true, just because the "overwhelming majority" proclaims it to be true is moronic. You cannot say "100 studies found this to be true, 2 found this to be false, therefore it is true". You have to examine the individual methodology of the papers. The point i'm trying to make here is that everyone leveling criticism at GMOs is considered a pariah immediately, as no one wants to risk their tenure and respectability by associating with people not conforming to the current opinion, even if the papers are peer reviewed. Take for example a compatriot of mine Dr Árpád Pusztai and his story. It is a similar problem to calling people unscientific or even anti-science immediately just because they voice anti-GMO sentiment. It's not that we are anti-science, it's that we are more critical of things.

For these reasons stated above being so unequivocally enthusiastic about GMOs and disregarding concerns leveled against them is dangerous.
This is despite the fact that i personally completely support research into genetically modified organisms, because i too believe that they might hold the key to the future. The difference being that i support research into it and not just immediately using them as soon as we have a viable "largely" nontoxic product.
If you bring the same careless attitude to all your other videos, as nicely as they are structured, and as cute as the animations are, i fear that any information i get out of them might be equally incomplete, and with a topic i know less about i might not even notice. Hence the unsubscription.

That 'organic, non gmo' shit is anything but, well, shit. It's no different, taste or nutrition wise, to the conventional grown food, and costs twice as much. It's a swindle. And because it's not sprayed with chemicals or modified to keep down bugs or diseases, very inefficient. You have to use double the space to grow the same amount, because of losses. Also, toss out that naive idea of organic veggies being grown on a quaint, single-family farm. The vast majority are owned by big food companies, and are farmed just the same as the regular ones, in huge monoculture fields nearly indistinguishable from thier contemporaries. Granted, they use less pesticides, but that doesn't men they use NONE. Yes, there are organic pesticides, as odd as that sounds, that are just as lethal and polluting as the regular stuff. And while the fertilizer is organic cow shit, it still runs off and chokes streams and rivers and helps with that lovely dead spot in the gulf. And, because cow shit packs less of a nutritional punch than the artificial kind, you need to use twice as much. Twice as much runoff! Yaaaaay.

And the crops themselves? they are bred to be bigger, more productive, and firm enough to withstand harvesting and shipping. Picked green so they won't bruise during the truck ride over, then gassed into artificial ripeness so your hippie ass can pay twice the amount for the same mealy, bland, tasteless shit that's in the shelf next to the hipster display.

Corrections for you:

There was indeed something of an objection to the notion of Terminator Genes (not seeds - not sure where you got that), but it's a nonsensical objection. Many crops are already sterile and provide no seeds, and even those that aren't do not provide good quality seeds, so as a practical matter, every farmer purchases a new blob of seeds every year, end of discussion. That's just how farming works. About the only logical objection to that would be some sort of hypothetical post-apocalyptic ferinstance, in which case we've already got independent activities going on to preserve seed stocks in the event of such an event.

Anything which allows for more extensive use of glyphosate (which I have always heard pronounced GLIFF-o-sate) over other herbicides is pretty much a solid win. There are no unique disadvantages to the substance, but there are some unique advantages. You are correct that it should not be the only method employed by farmers, but farmers tend to agree with you on that and most methodological approaches you might use to combat invasive weed species are less expensive than buying a jug of chemicals, and as such are generally tried first wherever it's a practical option.

You may or may not be aware of this, but using the terms "sustainable" and "agriculture" in the same sentence is absolutely begging for misunderstanding. For better or worse, that compound term was long ago seized by the organic nutjobs. While I agree that taking it back from dumb people who are using it to mean basically the opposite of what it means is a good thing, it's probably not something you can do yourself.

Bacillus thuringiensus is a touch more complicated than you let on. First off - and this is critically important when you're talking about subjects where crazy people like to locate their woo - it is not "completely harmless to humans." Getting anything remotely wrong about this subject in a way that might be seen as beneficial to one "side of the argument" will automatically disqualify everything you say to some people, and that's why it's vital to precisely and specifically outline this stuff when presenting this subject. Most strains only produce delta endotoxins (crystalline protein structures) that are indeed of no concern to mammals according to the harshest of animal studies, but some strains also produce beta endotoxins, and those ARE known to be toxic to humans. That, of course, is why we don't actually put the bacteria itself "in the plant," but instead only transfer the gene responsible for producing the delta endotoxins, thus reasonable ensuring that we get all the benefit of sprayed BT insecticide while alleviating one of the potential problems.

Fruit with higher antioxidant levels are not a concern for the vast and sweeping majority of nutritionists. Antioxidants are an essential micronutrient, but anybody in the developed world that consumes a diet more varied than three bowls of ramen noodles a day almost certainly has no problem. Don't buttress your information with woo - antioxidants are one of the most substantial and potentially the most damaging (studies indicate that, like with virtually everything, there is a healthful quantity of antioxidants to consume beyond which further consumption is actually deleterious to health) forms of diet nonsense on the market today.

GMO crops will never be "the next organic," and that is a good thing. Organic agriculture is a nonsense term used to describe the practice of farming deliberately utilizing only methods and resources that would have been available prior to the Green Revolution (around 1950). It is uniformly terrible for the environment, inefficient, produces no better nutritional or health outcomes in its results, and demands more land to even attempt to deliver similar yields. The crops themselves are basically unchanged. Bioengineered agricultural products are detectably and demonstrably different and produce identifiable savings and advantages. GMO and Organic are essentially the opposite of one another in every way that they can possibly be.

So why haven't scientists conducted a study where they feed one set of subjects nothing but GMO-foods (specifically foods from seeds produced using techniques like gene-splicing, not to be confused with selective breeding) from all the currently available GMO-foods being sold to the population and then compare their health to another set of subjects that eat nothing but organic fruits and vegetables? and then continue to feed them this way and monitor their health for decades to see the differences... This is a nearly impossible study (financially) but the only one capable of determining how safe GMOs really are. This type of study is why people speak up against GMOs, it's because there's really no way to conduct the study to know what effects will be determined long term. This is the main argument to put regulations on GMO's. The people who produce them keep throwing out words like "science has proven it's safe" and people will eat those phrases and studies as the scientific truth, but they are only true in a particular context of how the study was set up. Meanwhile, the mass population suffers from an increase in every disease known, and doctors continue to tell us they don't know what causes the increase. Until someone can figure out what causes the increases of infertility rates, increases in autism, cancer, Alzheimers, diabetes, you name it, until you can give me a scientific explanation why chronic diseases are rapidly increasing worldwide, I want to know if my food is GMO or not, the ppm of the pesticides on the food, and any other petroleum by-product in the food. This is not even factoring in the soil nutrient depletion rates, circumcision, prescriptions, vaccines etc. I don't understand why GMO proponents are not following this logical course of precaution and labeling their products appropriately? It's not that I think GMO's are going to kill me, it's that there's so many other problems that need to be resolved, and I don't have time to trust every GMO that is put out there. These companies have specifically modified with their only goal in mind of increasing yield or insect resistance. If that is their main motivation, to maximize gains or produce a substance toxic to insects, then I don't want anything to do with that particular GMO-food. On the other hand if the goal is to modify the food to maximize the nutrient contents specific to the health and well-being of the human body then I might considered their offer, but this would also require the soil to be modified organically to maximize the soil nutrients, but that costs money, and the GMO proponents are not interested in spending money, their food has to be affordable no matter what (sarcasm)!

GMO is nothing new, looking back to the beginning of the agricultural revolution people have always kept the best seeds from each crop. They plant those next year and do the same thing again. Over the past 1,000 years our food has changed a lot. Tomatoes where once all cherry tomatoes, and corn was very small.

We kept the seeds that mutated (with positive benefits) from the mother plants. We selectively choose what we wanted and did not want. It's the same process with modern GMO's except we are skipping the long waiting period in between the mutated seeds.

Fruit trees are one good example, all Red Haven peaches (the most popular peach sold in the US) are from the same mother plant. People planted tens of thousands of these trees until they found one that mutated just right. They took cuttings of that tree and graphed/rooted the cuttings to form a genetically identical clone. The Red Haven peach trees in my yard are the same exact plant that everyone else had. Same story with many tomatoes, pears, oranges, strawberry, apples, etc

I agree with Frazer Brooks. I don't appose genetic engineering that will help people, but multiple studies around the world have shown that many people can get severe allergic reactions to them, and many have died. Many farms that have grown GMO crops and have had lacking crop diversity in their fields have been reported to have had major nutritional loss in their soil. Many farms around the US have been abandoned as a result, which wastes land. Alfie Preston, you made a good argument that GMO crops can become resistant to deforestation and save the Amazon. However, would it not be the abandonment of farmland due to GMOs that would result in even more people burning down the Amazon for more farmland? The problem with many of these GMOs is that they may not have verifiably been tested on humans or other organisms. In fact, a possible problem of GMOs in the future would be that they could become invasive organisms and somehow have negative implications on wildlife that we could not possibly predict. Perhaps GMOs will become a great advantage in the future when our technology will become so advanced as to predict these possible negative implications. In this era, however, we have not yet reached that level of sophisticated genetic engineering, and must treat the subject with great care and allow those who wish to avoid GMO crops for fear of those implications to avoid them by making in necessary to label GMO products on the market. These people who keep asking questions like "But do GMOs do _?"

You can't ask a blanket question like that and get a straight answer. That's like asking "But can power tools drive a nail through wood?" I mean yeah, there are power tools capable of doing that, but you're not gonna get very far trying to drive a nail with a chainsaw. If you mean to ask "Can a GMO designed to do __ do __?", then yes, and if you fill those blanks with something bad then there's your answer, but geneticists aren't trying to fill those blanks with bad stuff.

There's no reason we'd have an unnatural side effects, either. GMOs aren't like prescription drugs where they're a cocktail of chemicals the brain has different reactions to, they're literally naturally-occuring genes spliced into plants and animals that don't already have those genes. If the genes do bad shit, they won't get spliced in. Super simple stuff.

The law of unintended consequences holds. With selective breeding you are working within an established framework, with straight GMO your are introducing elements that a biosphere may have no self regulatory mechanism. We already have had issues with corn crops and butterflies, bees and then we have secondary predators to those insects. Scientists can only do so much regression testing and scenario test cases. Your insecticide may kill the target insect, but now what happens has the dead insect is consumed, and so on. Too many variables and too many economic and political effects that can rub the genie lamp the wrong way.

Let's get this straight. There is a consensus among most scientists that GMOs are safe. Many of them are published by academics who state that their research has not been funded in any way by the biotech industry. There is a small minority of scientists who believe GMOs can be harmful, many of which have been debunked by reputable scientists. I find it hilarious that some people can believe in climate change, which also has scientific consensus with a few dissenters, but never that GMOs are not bad for you even though it has the same level of consensus.

And natural crossbreeding is actually more dangerous than GMOs. By controlling the exact genes (and therefore the proteins that are created from those genes), scientists can prevent any side effects whereas natural crossbreeding can have unintended side effects. There have already been cases of naturally crossbred celery and potatoes that have been toxic. Also GMOs undergo much more testing than natural crossbred plants, which is why workers in California who harvested a naturally crossbred subspecies of celery ended up with severe skin rash. Or how a potato, which naturally contain toxins, had elevated levels of this toxin after natural crossbreeding. A GMO that could possibly have this kind of an effect would not reach the market.

A main concern not addressed here are the ecological consequences for insects and birds, especially when the insect-killing genes spread to related native plants. Yes, some of these insects are 'pests' on crops, but these same insects in native systems are part of the ecosystem, and if the toxic effect is widespread is can impact more than just the target insects. If this toxin is tissue-stable, it will also then affect the birds and other animals who consume the insects (alive or dead), particularly baby birds who are fed exclusively on caterpillars (chickadees, robins, hummingbirds, etc)

A couple of things:

1) Hybridization is NOT the same as modern genetic engineering. This is a dishonest way of presenting it.
2) Of course "thousands of studies" say that GMO's are safe - because nearly all of them are very short term studies (think 60 to 90 days). Under that methodology, cigarettes would be considered safe.
3) We test for GMOs by looking at transgenes. Out of over 7 billion people, do we honestly think that nobody would be sensitive to these transgenes - similar to having an allergy. Imagine the hundreds of millions of other animals eating GMO crops. Do we believe that none of them have sensitives to these transgenes or the pesticides that many GMO crops now contain inside of them? The more GMOs we produce, the more likelihood of people all of a sudden having food sensitives to foods they've eaten their entire life simply because it's been tampered with.

Until we can address these issues, many people will continue to be against widespread GMO use in our food system.

If you want to feed the world you don't need to farm more intensely, you just need to stop adding an unnecessary middle-man in getting that energy and nutrition to humans - stop feeding the food to other animals and feeding the other animals to humans, it's inefficient.
Animals don't make calcium, or iron, or essential proteins, or omega-3 fats - they're made by plants, and stored in animals (humans included). Rather than wasting as much as 87.5% (by weight) of the food used to feed animals (conversion rate of grains to beef is 7:1) just feed it straight to humans and you can increase the food stock to the world by as much as 7 times (by weight).
Animal food is completely unnecessary and has been shown time and time again to be a major factor in the epidemic of the chronic disease that kill most people in the western world: heart disease, diabetes, etc. And we don't need to make more nutritious food to be healthier - just stop eating such unhealthy food like meat, dairy, and vegetable oils.

I love your videos and appreciate your well-researched information, but I think in this particular video you failed to fully explain the cons of GMO production. I agree that GMOs can provide powerful solutions to help feed people and reduce our environmental footprint--but as long as they are mainly being researched and developed by large afro-corporations like Monsanto, whose intentions are largely profit-based, I am skeptical that we will achieve these goals. Just look at how most GMOs are applied--to increase monocultures, force farmers into a cycle of buying the same seeds and pesticides forever, and taking out loans to do so--and its pretty obvious that GMO technology is dangerous. Maybe not by ingesting it, but through the socio-economic means of its control. You slightly touch on this in the video, but very superficially without giving us any suggestions on how to take GMO technology out of corporate hands and into the hands of small-scale farmers or non-profits. I hope in the future you will work to address this issue more holistically. Thank you!

I feel like the economic issues of GMOs was alluded to but not explained. The issue is that companies own GMO seeds (the seeds - LIFE - are patented) and thus, Farmers *must* buy from the same company year after year to grow the crops again - they become less and less economically independent. If they try to switch to different seeds or back to traditional farming, due to lingering contamination of previously used GMOs, farmers can and have been sued by the companies for seed copyright infringement. GMOs are life and life has a way of spreading easily. If for-profit companies didn't own and control GMOs, they could be used to help sustainable farming instead of fighting against it. Another issue is that it isn't in company's best interest to make GMOs sustainable - Monsanto sells buckets of the pesticide that their GMOs need.

There is a MASSIVE difference between Selective Breeding and Hybridization vs. Genetic Modification.
The first two takes a lot of time and therefor makes it easy to weed out harmful or otherwise unwanted genetic traits while Genetically Modified Organisms are created, tested, and mass-produced within the span of barely a decade at best .. and speaking of testing, the testing is done by the companies themselves while the agencies in North America and the European Union(not the individual European countries themselves) are LITERALLY trusting that the companies are 100% honest and forthcoming with the true results 100% of the times.
Genetically Modified Organisms are created by identifying and extracting the genetic sequence containing among other things the genetic information the scientists want to imbue the GMO-crop with, encapsulating it with gold, and bombarding seed-cells with it.

Herbicide-resistant crops have already started to result in herbicide-resistant weeds, and pesticide-producing crops have started to result in pesticide-resistant insects, and as such have caused farmers to use ever-increasing amounts of herbicide and had to turn to external pesticides that are dangerous to all living creatures.

The Genetically Modified Organisms produced to survive in inhospitable climates have been found out to either yield the same amount for the same water and labor, or although being much stronger yielding a lesser amount, or yielding crops that is not as nutritious.

The Genetically Modified Organisms has also resulted in an even faster rate of mono-cultural agriculture due to the damages Round-UP Ready crops and similar crops have caused to the soil and groundwater.

Income of poor farmers in Third World countries have WORSENED after they started growing GMO-crops on their fields due to rapidly increasing costs and predatory contracts.
The only farmers in Third World countries that have benefited from growing GMO-crops are big agricultural farmers who already profited before the introduction of GMO-crops.

Also, we can not grow more food out of the same land without causing soil-depletion, which already is a huge problem we face TODAY due to super-intensive farming.

And if you want to feed more people with the amount of food we produce right now it is far easier to stop the GIGANTIC food-waste we already cause, we could feed almost twice as many people just with the food we already create, and it does NOT require ANY Genetic Modification AT ALL
Furthermore we can increase crop-yields by utilizing architectural innovation so that we can grow food Vertically instead of just Horizontally on the same acreage, and we can utilize innovations in engineering to grow large yields of crops inside cities without encroaching on land used for housing.

One thing that troubles me greatly about how GM foods are presented by every reputable scientific outlet is that they are touted as wholly good, and any of the potential dangers are minimalized. From my perspective it seems as though neither side of the discussion takes an objective view. Anti-GMO groups are whole heartedly against the notion of modifying our food in such a way. I fall somewhere in the middle, where I can absolutely see the benefits, but I'm closer to the anti-gmo side of the argument. You just barely touched upon perhaps the best argument against the widespread use of GM crops: Terminator seeds and genetic drift. It truly bothers me how the scientific community brushes these things off as though they are of little to no concern and pose no threat. We can't even predict the weather accurately more than a week in advance. How can we possibly take into account the millions of variables involved in using GM crops uncontained? Even if it's not in our lifetime there's a real potential to irreparably damage our biosphere and the scientific community brushes it off. What I really see going on is corporate interests forcing a product on the world that we don't actually need, most people don't want.

Humans have not "genetically modifying for thousands of years". That's called selective breeding and it's not a genetic modification in any way. There is no modification being performed on plant of animal that is selectively bred. Regardless if one is pro or against genetic modifications and regardless of what the safety of the practice might be, stating that selective breeding is the same as genetic modification it's at the very least grossly inaccurate if not an outright falsehood, though thankfully some disclosures are later made about difference between genetically engineering modifications to add specific traits the video should also have said how today's GM is performed, like for instance using live e-coli, viruses or other bacteria to "splice" a new genetic sequence inside a plant/seed in a lab. And those are live organism, not just pieces of harmless genetic code. The info on it is far too superficial, oversimplified and "sanitized" for mass consumption.
Furthermore to say that something if harmless to humans isn't accurate nor true as in not enough long term studies have been made (GMO have been around less than 100 years and certainly less in the modern methodology they are created today and on the scale they are used and abused today. And the "thousands of studies being made are far too often performed by the very same companies that stand to gain from GMO. Those made independently are systematically buried and hidden, when not bought over or "ceased and desisted" by those who performed it so avoid losses and lawsuits they can't possibly afford. Not to mention the socio economic impact they have when controlled in unfair and dishonest practices aiming to achieve monopoly and ownership of entire markets (see cotton and Indian farmers for instance). It's definitely possible that some GMOs might be harmless in the long run, but no company would wait the time it would take to ensure they are truly safe as commercialization as soon as possible is the only reason why GMO even exists... and little matters if pesticides, herbicides include well known carcinogens banned in the resto of the world, or if any other ingredient or process will or may causes harm to humans, animals, insects or might have an adverse impact on the environment.

Just a little detail ! Most Bt crops have a root promoter upstream the toxin expression gene. This means that crops like Bt corn express the toxin on the root and not on the actuall fruit, so you don't actually consume the toxin (which actually can be harmful to humans in large dosis). This is because many of the target predators attack the root of the crops, not the whole plant.

Great video, but I would just like to point out (and I know this doesn't happen very often) that you let a little pseudo-science pop into your video there.

At 6:50 you mentioned supplementing anti-oxidants, but the science is largely in on that subject. Anti-oxidants are not healthy, and certain anti-oxidants are actively harmful. The body produces all the anti-oxidants it needs and adding more is not helpful.

The 2012 Cochrane review is the best source on this subject (http://www.cochrane.org/CD007176/LIVER_antioxidant-supplements-for-prevention-of-mortality-in-healthy-participants-and-patients-with-various-diseases), but if you need more just search for anti-oxidants on the Cochrane library site and you'll get an extensive list of conditions they do not help with.

Lastly, thank you for the videos and keep up the good work.

-Pest-proof crops are also suspected to kill vital beneficial bugs, such as bees and butterflies.

-Another side effect of GMOs is their “dust clouds”. GM farming involves exposing the topsoil which contains high levels of pesticides. This exposure allows the wind to blow dust clouds onto nearby farms, communities and water sources, thus contaminating other crop growth and entering the drinking water. Moreover, the erosion of topsoil can be so severe that when the GM farming ceases, the land is left in such poor condition that it cannot be farmed for 20 years.

(please note I wrote this when I was 14 so yes, there may be things that have not been taken into account)

I have the impression a whole side of the analysis is missing here.

We can't control nature. Despite our best efforts, we simply don't have the knowledge and resources to simulate evolution on such a scale. GMOs have the potential to be a catastrophy : a simple mistake, or a mutation we could not predict, and we could end up with uncontrolable pests, trees so resistant they destroy all their neighbors (and bio diversity with them), etc.
This is, in a way, playing god. The "classic" genetic engineering kept pace with normal evolution, but genetic mutations goes way beyond that.

It's also important to point out that a lot of pest and diseases problems we face today with our crops are results of too much genetic engineering : by keeping only 1 specie of banana, the one which produces the biggest and tastiest bananas, we made our "banana industry" fragile. A simple disease touching this particular specie can put countries on their knees, like you said in your video. This happened numerous times. Genetic diversity in farming must be restored.

I'm quite surprised your analysis has been so simplified. I share a lot of your optimism about science, and genetic engineering. This could save lifes, and our planet. But we need to confront the fact that we are still beginners in this field, and that the impact of a bad mutation / human error could be huge. And that's without speaking of the ethical issue, especially about genetically modified animals and on day, humans.

I don't care much for his explanation here. Let me explain. First off, being genetically engineered is vastly different from being selectively bred, because being genetically engineered with foreign dna is something that can not naturally occur. Second, our knowledge of genomes is far less than this video leads you to believe. That in itself is reason not to trust such a method, though that was not mentioned at all. Third, Laboratories can be bought out much the same as any other company, though the risk in doing so is extremely high. I highly doubt anything aforementioned has or would happen, but his explanation lacked too little few perspectives to allow anyone to truly make a decision.

Looks and Sounds like a mainstream PR response to me. What this video fails to mention, are the methods used to create the GMO products in question, and the genetic side effects that result in those who consume these products. GMOs are created by introducing a retro-virus into the DNA of a plant or animal, in order to forcefully insert certain genetic properties into that plant or animal from another plant or animal by splicing those genes into the DNA of E-coli virus and then infecting the target with the altered "retro-virus" resulting in unstable and unpredictable outcomes in the test subject. Consuming such a product can cause permanent changes in the biology of those who consume said product, starting at the digestive level by introducing that retro-virus to the good bacteria in your digestive tract. Creating an irreversible change in that good bacteria and Impacting overall health , literally the digestive tract will never again work the way it should , ever again.  Everything just compounds itself from there until your immune system is so overworked trying to repair irreparable damage that continuous exposure to this foreign substance creates. Eventually leading to irreversible mutations of the DNA in the people and animals that consume the so called safe GMOs.

The main problem of GMO isn't their potential toxicity, even if they currently were toxic that's a problem that could be solved in the future. The real problem of GMO in their current use is patents and more importantly their promoting of cultivating plants coming from one single gene strand for thousands of square miles while trying to kill everything else.

I like the video, but I feel like it only lightly touches on two major concerns with GMO's. One is the fact that, as created organic products, a company can copyright them. The company owning the patent for the crop can legally go after farmers who are found to have said genetic profiles in their crops (a thing that has happened), even if the genetics were introduced through natural pollination. The other lesser voiced concern is that a genetic profile that ultimately proves harmful for human consumption but is chosen for other, commercial reasons (taste, color, firmness, yield, etc) could spread, and in turn be hard to remove, from the totality of a strain of plant. I don't wish to say GMO's are a science we shouldn't pursue with these comments, but these are large, and valid concerns that need further addressing.

As a genetic engineering researcher, I would like to say that this is a great video but errs on the optimistic side on what we will soon be capable of. Yes, we are making directed gene changes to plants that allow them to carry more diverse traits, but just the simple act of adding additional genes can affect viability. In other words, asking cells to carry out more jobs tends to make those cells less likely to survive or have enough energy to carry out basic tasks. Individual studies or products used in industry are able to have slightly altered activities, such as producing pesticides naturally produced by entirely different species, but combining these into a single engineered plant that can survive drastically different conditions on Mars is challenging. This is because compounding gene changes together tends to add exponential complexity and difficulty from the human perspective. So yes, this may very well be possible some day, but do not take any of the examples or graphics from this video as literally true/existing technologies today unless they are directly referenced. Definitely trust and investigate the references, but not all of the visuals represent our current capabilities.

As a Conservative American, I believe that GMO's can be good. (Wait, what?) You read that correctly, they can be good... but here's the warning. We have to be extremely careful HOW we make GMO foods. Here's why.

If we go all gung-ho and unthinkingly and non-skeptically apply any GMO product we make, we run the risk of having unrealized, and unanticipated side-effects that only pop-up many decades later.  In a different way, America did a similar thing when we first started farming the Central US, and had bad soil-tilling practices. (This caused the "Dust Bowl" years.)

If we use bacteria to introduce DNA into crops, how do we know the weeds, and other plants, won't get some of those bacteria on them and acquire the exact gene we were trying to fight them with?

We have mapped many genomes, but mostly in a general sense.  The genome is a language that we've only learned by "seeing" a gene expressed and learning the "word" that the gene is associated with. It's like pointing to a butterfly and saying it's blue without knowing that it "reflects" blue without the actual fibers "being" blue. How do we know where exactly the bacteria inserted the DNA into the plant?  What if it inserted it in the "middle" of an existing gene (messing it up) as opposed to inserting it "between" 2 genes.  My concern here could be in the discovery of new cancers that only develop after multiple generations pass without any issue.

We need to be careful about side-effects that may take a very long time to even occur, and even longer to be discovered.  When we first discovered radiation, we were all like "lets irradiate stuff for simple medical conditions" and "lets x-ray mosquito bites." We also tried separating the 2 halves of people's brains that had psychological issues (not the best ideas, I'm sure you'd agree.)  It would be extremely naïve of us to automatically assume that bad choices like this would never happen in the study of GMOs, so (yet again) we need to be careful about How we develop GMOs, How we spread GMO foods, and How we monitor and study the environmental and health effects (if any at all) of them.

Like everything we discover, it's amazing, just except those few % when we make an "accidentally" huge mistake with it.

GMOs are the main reason for many of the problems in modern agriculture. Many weeds and insects have developed immunity or resistance to glyphosate. While pesticides kill harmful insects they also in many cases kill the natural predators of those insects or make those predators uninterested in eating them. We would not have this type of problem if there was a proper crop rotation and reasonably sized growing fields. It is very much the same thing as mice or rat problems, if you provide large and sustainable quantity of food for rodents, soon there will be a big problem with them.

Biggest problem today is that the ground layer of USA crop fields is so contaminated with glyphosate that anything that has not been genetically engineered cannot grow on that ground. Meanwhile many weeds and insects can resist this pesticide. These large companies have destroyed the growing fields in USA and eventually there will be nothing left that grows on that ground.

Organic farming has been shown to yield just as much food at a lower overall cost. Why organic food is more expensive then? Simply because there is more demand than production.

I am still doubtful. I am not a scientist, but I am rational and informed enough to question some of the things you say here:

1) comparing mixing genes "naturally" by selection of better/fitter representants of one same species, and mixing genes "scientifically" from, say, a bacteria and from some corn in order to make the make the corn virus resilient is hardly the same thing, IMHO. It's more than just a change in the technical approach of the same thing. If GMO was indeed selecting the best corn genes to match them up with best corn genes, then it would be. It is not.

2) The use of sterile seeds is STILL COMPLETELY IN USE AND LEGAL in many countries, like India. That's Monsanto-Bayer main source of income, isn't it ? Why you just suggest that problem is solved ?

3) How come buffer zones (that should be huge to be effective) can be part of the "let's use less land to produce more" idea ?

4) Studies generally do show that GM food is not harmful to us. But ending the video by suggesting we could make GM food BETTER to us (more vitamins, etc.) totally ruins that argument: if GM food can be positively affecting us, how can you be so sure it won't affect us negatively ? Because it's engineered that way ??

5) Using GMO is so far, as you said yourself, linked to the idea of monoculture, which ruins the grounds, makes the plants weaker (hence the need for other ways to defend them against pests, like pesticides and GMO), and present all sorts of ethical and economical issues. SO going full GMO is, so farm going further in a model that is suicidal.

6) You don't talk about something that could look trivial, but actually still matters: do GM foods have good taste, or even some taste ??

Bottom line: GMOs are a tool, and they COULD be used the greater good, better food, more sustainable agriculture, etc. They also COULD be used to simply maximize profit and production, in the detriment of safety, farmers, consumers, gastronomy, biodiversity.
And guess what ? So far, it REALLY looks like the latter is happening.
So no, am not convinced.

We don't need to engineer plants that fix nitrogen - we've already got them. They're called legumes - beans, peas, peanuts, etc. We don't need to engineer chestnut trees, either - we already have chestnut trees (See Shepard's farm, and the Dunstan chestnut for two examples of selection and hybridization). Most of the arguments for GMOs here are to fix a problem introduced by monoculture cropping and industrial agriculture. Look at New Forest Farm in Wisconsin (Mark Shepard's Restoration Agriculture) and permaculture for but two examples of how we can feed everyone on the planet, with better quality food than can be grown using industrial ag and/or with GMO efforts.

Something you missed with regards to BT crops is natural selection and evolution. BT was supposed to reduce the amount of pesticides that needed to be used - and initially it did. But it kills everything - including beneficial insects that would keep predators in check. It also doesn't kill all predators - the ones that survive are immune to BT. Now the farmer has a field full of super bugs that love munching on the BT corn - and not only does he need to get back to spraying, but he needs more frequent doses of stronger pesticides to kill the super bugs. No. Just No.

Since the introduction of GMO food crops in America, we have seen a dramatic increase in food allergies. BT genes aren't deadly poisonous to humans, but they do damage human intestines. The result is partially undigested food leaking from the intestines and causing an immune reaction that renders a human allergic to that food. Intestinal problems like Celiac's disease (gluten allergy) increased markedly in humans and domestic animals after the introduction of GMO foods. The reason we don't hear more about the studies proving GMO foods harmful is that the people appointed to lead the US FDA and Department of Agriculture for the past 20 years have often been corporate lobbyists or former food/chemical company executives with a vested interest in the profitability of the companies they worked for. The opinions of actual scientists are ignored in favor of political appointees. My mother suddenly developed a gluten allergy 7 years ago and has been hospitalized twice when her intestines nearly ruptured. Educate yourself about GMO foods with real scientific data instead of Monsanto adverts like this.  People didn't know DDTs and Agent Orange could hurt people at first, either.

It's frustrating to hear the inaccurate narrative that genetic engineering is thousands of years old. It's simply untrue. The true statement would be that we have been selecting for positive traits at the level of the phenotype for thousands of years but the technology to manipulate, transpose, or rewrite a single gene is brand new technology. If this oft-repeated statement were true then the last half century of patents for novel genetic technology would all be overturned. There are some good arguments made in this video but opening with this obvious falsehood undermines them.

You've also ignored some of the rational arguments made against GMOs such as the potential for using gene drive technology to artificially increase the genetic fitness of a given trait. In addition many of the solutions you offer such as golden rice and hyper efficient carbon sequestration by chestnuts have already been proven to be failures due to having such a small effect size.

I offer these criticisms in good faith. I believe there is great potential for GMO technology to do good in the world but it's so important to keep our arguments honest.

The problem with any sort of study concluding that "GMOs are fine", is that you can't conclusively prove such a massively broad, generalized statement like that. Even supposing that it is true that all current GMOs on the market today are perfectly safe and good, that doesn't necessarily mean that any and every possible future modification we might make will be similarly safe.

I'm certainly not opposed to the idea of creating and using GMOs in general, but we have to exercise caution to ensure that each individual modification we make doesn't create problems in the future.

I'm 100% on board with GMOs, I just wish people were more willing to embrace caution with how we implement them. Moving too quickly and especially allowing corporations to set the course could be disastrous. Say a modification that seems beneficial in the short term turns out to be very detrimental over generations, but we let the original species die out and can't go back. Or say a corporation gets control of the copyright for a species and claims a monopoly over a staple food. Monsanto has already used seed copyrights to bankrupt small farmers. GMOs seem great, but don't denounce counterarguments out of hand, that's not scientific.

Lastly, the claim that we've been genetically engineering foods for thousands of years is somewhat inaccurate. Certainly we've been modifying species through selective breeding, but we're talking about crazy new technologies like viral injection of new sequences of DNA. That's a fundamentally different technology, just as cloning is fundamentally different from normal live birth in several ways even though the result might be the same.

GMOs are not what concern me ... I am concerned about the conflict of interest between the companies making both the seed and the associated herbicides, fungicides, larvacides, etc.

It does not seem likely that making product A (GM crop) would be in their best bottom line to reduce the sales of product B (Glyphosate, for example)... I've seen some studies suggesting that Glyphosate applications in the US are reducing, but they are filled with design flaws and conflicts of interest... So I remain skeptical of the intentions of the producers.

A serious question, if you will: how have these governmental and scientific bodies reached the conclusion that GM crops are safe without a single clinical human trial? I understand there are animal studies, but pharmaceuticals must be held to extremely high standards of safety. If we are so sure that GM crops are entirely safe, there should be no concerns of ethics, and therefore a study to test a hypothesis regarding human safety. Yes?

Another serious question: While pretty and fun to look at in the video, have there been conclusions of modern GM monoculture crops on soil ecology when sprayed with Glyphosate? What effects, if any does this have?

I do love some of the ideas of various applications of GM crops, particularly to help climate change, but I remain unconvinced of the intentions of the large seed companies... Unlike many "Anti-GM'ers" I am certainly open to new information, but view the matter with a cautious eye.

While GMOs are beneficial if used properly, what people don't know is that it has been misused for decades. For example, Monsanto, an agrochemical company, has patented it's own GMO soy and corn seeds, and has a huge monopoly on these crops in North America. By planting these crops, the GMO pollens pollinates non-GMO crops owned by local and private farmers. This results in the farmers non-GMO crops to produce GMO crops. The farmers are then sued by the Corp for planting patented seeds, and without evidence to say otherwise, is put out of business the ensuing weeks and months. Another example is the use of herb-/pesticide. China being the biggest user of herb-/pesticides, unsurprisingly uses herb/-pesticides that are toxic not only to bugs and weed but to humans as well in the long term, and causes environmental damages. These herb-/pesticides are banned in many parts of the world, including here in Canada. Small time researchers that come up with safe pest-/herbicides are quickly snuffed out by companies that produces the cheaper toxic herb-/pesticides. So when these are used on herb-/pesticide resistant crops, unforeseen damages occur, such as the endangerment of bees that pollinates the majority of the world's crop supplies that feed us and the animals that we eat (applies to fake vegans). Quite impartial video, but even then:

1) GMOs are seen bad essentially because of the way multinational firms use them, and as you said we DO need to change the way agriculture is run in the 21st century. BUT THEN you say GMOs could stop deforestation in order to feed livestock, WHY NOT advocating for reducing meat production instead, as many organisations also believe? This would also reduce immensely soil pollution and global warming, but also free even more space for crop cultivation.

2) You talked about glyphosate, why not then speaking about the hundreds of farms where weeds have become resistant to Roundup and other glyphosate pesticides, and that now we can't get rid of these weeds as they have become so resistant to anything? THAT IS why self-defending GMO crops are not seen as viable by many because insects might develop resistance to certain molecules these tailored GMO crops.
This is what a lot of people are scared about, and it is not the only case, as in the medical field the same thing is happening with antimicrobic resistant (AMR), where in some parts of the world the meat industry uses so much antibiotics on its cattle that very soon we could face a very plausible "post antiobtic era" (didn't you guys make a video about it btw?)

ALSO, I've been watching all your videos for a long time now, so thank you for the time to make this video, and most of us know that you can't cover everything in a 9mn video; and thanks for opening a debate about GMOs. I myself am against GMOs because of the way they are used and that we need several more decades to REALLY now all the good and bad that may come out of GMOs (like the bangladeshi eggplant, which may reveal to be not so amazing in the end). BUT I do hope that in a near future GMOs will be safe but especially USED safely, which is a whole different debate, as you said in the video.

Actually, the foolish comparison of early Man's selective breeding of livestock in mundane animal husbandry between variations of the same or similar species (generally limited to species/genus/family) to modern genetic modification, in a laboratory, gene-splicing lifeforms unnaturally in a test tube between VASTLY DIFFERENT SPECIES (we're talking crossover abominations between PLANT AND ANIMAL KINGDOMS(!!!)) takes a lot of chutzpah.

What are the moral ramifications of creating a pig-orange? Or salmon-corn? Or salmon-strawberries? Or pine-corn? OR GOAT-SPIDERS? OR JELLYFISH-RABBITS? Each of the former examples I just listed, with the exception of goat-spiders due to public outcry, HAVE ALREADY BEEN CREATED WITH GENETIC MODIFICATION. I invite you to look them up! EDIT: Nevermind, goat-spiders have been created TOO!

And, contrary to your assertion, THERE EXISTS NO MAGICAL GRAND BOARD OF REVIEW to regulate what companies can and cannot do with genetic modification. There, desperately, needs to be one. Or many.

Also, you kind of glossed over the reason the public is angered over"terminator seeds" and "gene flow" without connecting the two. The "undesirable traits" that could be transferred from GMO plants to natural plants is the terminator seed gene. That's why the public is angry; the threat of pollen from these sterile gmo plants sterilizing natural varieties the world over. Which would, or course, force us to rely upon bio-engineering firms to then feed us$$$$$$$$$$$$$$, making us their owned chattel even more.

And international bio-engineering firms, like the big warm cuddly friendly Monsanto, would certainly be profit motivated to -- oops -- accidentally engineer their sterile designer plants to cross-pollinate with natural plants -- effectively wrecking the fecundancy and fertility of natural crops the world over so that the world would then rely upon buying the seed for their expensive designer GMO plants EVERY YEAR. Or starve.

Think Monsanto -- a big cuddly multinational corporation -- wouldn't be interested in world domination? Look up the company's history.Look up a nice neutral article -- such as the "Controversy" section at their Wikipedia page. Making colossal dumpster fires all over the world. Very shady folks -- even when put in the best of light.

EDIT: I believe in the Science behind genetic modification; I just don't trust the humans the scientists are hired slaves to.

The primary problem with GMOs actually has nothing to do with health risks or morality. This problem may or may not exist today, but it did when people first started modifying the genes of crops. I'm surprised they didn't talk about it in the video.

All plants create pollen and attract insects and use the wind to move it to other plants; it's how they spread their genes. The wind and insects can carry the pollen from plant to plant, which fertilizes the eggs (seeds) of each one. Once fertilized, the seed is produced and a new plant will grow. This can happen between farms, even when they are acres apart. This is natural, and is normally good.
When GM plants were first mass produced, there was only one company doing it. You can actually patent the technology, so that no one else can GM their plants in exactly the same way you did to yours. This patent also extends to the crop. The patent labels all plants that carry the same genetic modifications as the patent owner's (until it's bought by a consumer, of course).

What happened was when a GM plant fertilized a non-GM plant, in the way that all plants do, it would always have the modification, even in the child plant. You see, we don't want to modify every seed, so the modifications are coded to be dominant, and therefore always inherited in the child plants. Because of the patent, if the GMO company found any plants that carried the modifications in another farm's crops, then they could legally be accused of patent violation, and could claim the entire farm. This happened numerous times, actually. Lawyers and scientists were dispatched to nearby farms to test crops for their modifications, and if even a single plant carried the modification, they claimed the farm. As a result, many private farmers lost their livelihood to the GMO company in their area, and that's why they're hated so much.

We have mapped the entire genome of most of our food plants, so we know what we're doing. There are no variables in modifying genes and, in reality, no health risks in food that has been labelled safe. The fight against GMOs was not about health, but human rights infringement. The private farmers needed all the support they could get, so they invented a lot of reasons why GMOs were bad, because they couldn't win the legal battle over who the crops belonged to.

In short, GMOs are perfectly safe and previous patent laws are too obsolete for this technology

The reason why the insuline that's acquired from genetically engineered sources doesnt' arise suspicion is because, ultimately you are producing 1 very specific substance. It's like looking at a box full of red balls, you're going to immediately notice if one of those balls is blue. The difference with food is that there you have a massively complex mix of different macromolecules, vitamines and other complex systems. I'm sure the risks are minimal, but I still think that it's not zero. 30 years is long for us, but in terms of the sustainability of a species, it's really very short. Maybe some of the adverse consequences won't start to show up until the 100th generation down the line.

Granted, at that point the threads we're plucking are so subtle, you're certainly going to suffer more harm from something as simple as taking a puff from a cigarette, or using benzene based cleaning products. So, a person shouldn't complain too much about GMOs if they are doing any number of other activity that involves such potentially harmful chemicals.

If that company has so much power then it could sway inspections and potentially kill off portions of our world slowly by introducing a negative GMO that seems like it's a positive one. The fear isn't baseless, in order for the change to take place there has to be a different mindset in the business sector not only in the public sector. Perhaps capitalistic models wouldn't work well at all because it's too much profit oriented?

When you give big agra business free reign to patent DNA sequences, all this innovation you talk about will be stifled, non-gmo farmers will be pushed out of business or sued for having gmo weeds growing on their land, and pesticides will become an even bigger problem for surrounding ecology. Gene patenting potentially allows a few corperations to act with an insurmountable amount of power. A monopoly on agriculture is basically game over. People have the ability not to purchase certain things like sunglasses, films, smartphones etc, but everybody must buy food er else die. Owning a monopoly on agriculture, something will only be accelerated by GMOs (without regulation), is a guaranteed licence to print money. The comment in the video about terminator seeds doesn't mention a little know fact. The vast majority of commercial farms don't plant seeds from the previous harvest any way. It's just leaving too much to chance that way.
Cereal crops like wheat or canola use fresh seeds from a seed supply every spring, and annual crops like grapes, oranges or apples use cuttings from known producing plants to start a new farm.

Why? Well take cereal crops for example, the seed supply company guarantees a germination percentage, say 97% are guaranteed to sprout. With using the previous harvest's seeds a farmer could hit that, but there's no way to know. And farming is such a precarious occupation that even one really bad season can be enough to put a farm under. It's just not worth the gamble. So they just don't do it if they're smart. It has lead to the problem of monoculture crops and the loss of crop diversity, but this was a problem due to the practice I stated long before GMOs arrived on the scene. Using terminator seeds won't create any sort of problems for commercial farming AFAIK.

GMO is like any other technology. It has great promise but with potential drawbacks, some known, others unknown or only speculated on. A complete rejection of GMO is foolish and short sighted IMHO. But we do need to be cautious and resist the urge to go in blind. Good scientific methods and well thought out regulation will go a long way to mitigating any potential problems instead of an outright rejection of the technology.
