0:43 this is BS. There is a difference between Genetic Modifying organisms and Selective Breeding (Artificial Selection) them. Implying that GMO==Selective Breeding is dishonest.
Selective Breading is a relatively slow process with tons of limitations, it imitates natural evolution and is very gradual. Modern genetic modifications that people are scared of is a fast process where you can leapfrog many steps or even create something that would be impossible to achieve by artificial selection.
Saying that selecting better suited tomatoes is the same as injecting genes from a fish into tomatoes is like saying that carving and moulding are the same.

This video brings up a important question, Why is genetic modification to develop better medicines considered acceptable? Yet genetic modification of food is met with such distrust. First one misconception, If people understood that certain medicine was genetically modified, and they knew which medicine. There would be a objection to that as well.
Now where does all this distrust of the tool of GMO come from? Well to answer that you have to look no further than the anti-vaccine movement.
People do not trust the oversight that goes into the implementation of GMO's. But for medicines people generally have the notion that it that gets tested and scrutinized much more than non-medical applications. If a medicine kills or permanently impairs, maims, or otherwise damages a person, its much easier to trace back to the problem to the medicine in question. Pharmaceutical company's know this, so they are extra cautious, because they do not want the lawsuits or bad press. Even if it takes awhile for the ill or bad effects to show up. Now even with Pharmaceutical company's being cautious, deadly and damaging medication does make it into the marketplace. Granted its not common but it happens.

Now for GMO foods, people do not see the same oversight as often exists medical applications of GMO's. Plus it much harder to trace back food that makes people ill or sick. Especially if its over long term exposure. Making it harder to prove or win lawsuits.Thus insulating them from bad press, and the lawsuits.
Both sides of these are out to make money, and its well known if a shortcut can be gotten away with. Greed will drive corporations and people to exploit this. Its not like this has not happened before.

 
Essentially people have complete lack of trust in government and oversight to act in their public's best interest. Instead they expect government's and oversight committees to act in there own interests, with the driving forces of greed, and self interest.

There are solutions that don't always require pesticides and splicing in bacteria DNA. One is to go back to growing crops without depleting the soil of nutrients - and creating a growing environment that mimics nature. Ground cover such as rotting wood and leaves for example are usually what plants thrive in. We strip all that stuff away in modern farms, then we have to add those nutrients back in with expensive chemicals. Lack of nutrients causes weak plants that are more susceptible to insects and disease so we have to modify them to resist those newer diseases. Without natural ground cover plants also dry out faster and we have to use more water and also genetically modify plants to resist dry conditions. Without that natural ground cover water evaporates rapidly since there is no barrier there any more. The newer farming practices cause many problems and the solutions may be spun as saving humanity - but we actually caused most of the problems ourselves in our own ignorance. If we combined the new GMO's such as drought resistant plants and natural growing techniques, we'd have the best of both worlds.

lies and more tales, say NO to GMO!!!  there is some really bad and misleading information here and straight out tales, I must point out that the major concern about GMO crops is the fact that they are introducing genes to make the plant pest resistant, the means that they go about doing this is by introducing a modification to the genetic sequence of the plant so it will naturally produce enzyme inhibitor substances,  pests need enzymes to be able to digest the cellulose-rich leaves and bits of the plant,  they ingest the plant along with the enzyme inhibitor,  the bug can't digest it because it can no longer produce as much enzyme, so the " bug " will die out before it can reproduce and complete their life cycle, this has an impact on other species that are not classified as pests, including humans!!!!!!   last time i checked humans rely on enzyme production to digest food also, and as far as i know, human enzyme production is a limited one, human enzyme production deficit is associated with aging , old people have a harder time digesting foods because the enzyme production is very diminished, very old people will even have other health issues related to not being able to digest and extract nutrients from food they eat, so, enzymes are more related to aging process than anyone is willing to admit, and they don't want you to know that!!!! once you start adding enzyme inhibitors to the food chain even in very small amounts it will stack up fast, this is why everyone should say NO to GMO food !  hands off my food please!

Only reason why GMO is needed is monoculture approach to agriculture. Bigger and bigger harvest means that the soil is getting more and more depleted, nutrients to make fruit don't pop out of thin air. This approach is gradually turning North America and Europe into a desert, and soon we won't be able to grow anything. Artificial fertilizer will not help keeping water in the soil, or putting air into it, if all herbi-and pesticides kill all of the insects, fungi and plants in the soil. If we decide to completely sterilise our planet until it's infertile, and then plant only the things that produce food for us, we might end up with production costs going through the roof.
With permaculture on the other hand - clever design in which often wild variants of plants and animals interact in a complex ecosystem we can have more diverse and abundant food, that doesn't require pesticides, herbicides, plowing, watering or fertilizing. It will balance itself out and give us enough food to go by, if we design it cleverly.

I think the real issue of GMO is the seemingly unethical behaviours of the companies that produce and sells them. In marketing, many producers jump to get certain types of labeling as it adds an element of trust to the consumers. But, when companies pays millions each year to stop and to hide what's in their products, then it leave the consumer wondering just what they're trying to keep from us and why. It's not unreasonable to want to know what's in the food you eat.

The argument is, "you either tell us what's in your products or we won't buy them".. Ignoring us for whatever reason is one thing, but spend million each year to keep us from asking is a completely difference and unreasonable situation.

While we may believe that science is always constant, we have to understand that scientists may not be. Example, in the 70's it was widely reported that by doctors, based on scientific research that butter was bad for you and margarine was a better alternative. Today, it turns out that it is actually that margarine is more damaging that butter ever was.

My point is, not accepting research is not the same as not accepting research sponsored by companies that stand to gain from the result of that research - this is even worst when those same company lobbies politicians to help them hide the complete findings and lobbies the FDA to dismiss any concerns.

Because of these practices we end up with "fruit juices" that contains less than 2% of actual juice from fruits...

Take a look at what happened in the 70's also with the report in congress on sugar. You ever wonder why that "sugar" on the nutrition fact labeling does not carry a percentage while everything else has? Do you think that perhaps it could very well be that the amount of sugar used in today's products is way over the recommended daily dietary intake?
What if we're not the pinnacle of evolution but the manifestation of evolution itself..?

2:06 So the anti-GMO crowd protest that GM-plants breed, but also when they don't breed. Is it just an excuse to demonize with or is there actually an issue? I don't see a problem with either way of doing it.

2:17 GMOs growing where they weren't planted? Sure. I suppose this is possible. But that's true of ANY crops, GM or otherwise, right? (Unless they're terminator seeds.)

2:46 "Is food that comes from GM-crops different from food that comes from non-GM-crops?" Other than the fact that they're different organisms, I don't see how. Why is this is a concern? What mechanism could make GMOs dangerous that isn't worse in uncontrolled GM techniques like simply breeding or atomic gardening, etc?

4:15 About the pesticide problem: It's a problem for any and all crops, GM or otherwise. The difference is that with GM, the pesticides are more effective and less damaging to the crops, meaning that less land is needed to be farmed for the yield, meaning less harm to the environment. Am I overlooking anything?

4:30 Simply saying that there are businesses that profit from GM-technology can also be said of any industry. GM and non-GM alike. +Kurgesagt - In a Nutshell

I had an interesting debate with a good friend of mine about genetics just the other day. With GMOs becoming more widely spread, other ways of genetic engineering to try (and I emphasize the word try) helping with our impact on the world while helping us. Out of this discussion came a new subject to scientists that was fantasy to many people of the 80s-2012, but now may become a reality within the next 100 years. You did a similar video to this before, about genetics and their benefits to us in the long run, though as said, this is a new, unexplored, and controversial subject. I say controversial due to the fact it is beyond different, and goes against many people's ethics. Within the future, modifying our bodies using gene therapy, gene splicing, other gene related substances, and/or machines will become a norm...if we don't outlaw them. The new idea is basically replacing the dog workforce within our military and police force with genetically modified humans. Now, I know what most would say, that's unethical to put humans in danger rather than dogs, but just hear me out. These genetically modified humans could serve more roles than replacing dogs or even scanning equipment. The idea itself is to drastically change a person to look, breathe, and hear differently to a Human, often taking animal characteristics, but in all reality, the cheaper option would be "simple" genetic changes that would change some internal things, but nothing "major". This could breed entirely new species on the planet Earth, fulfilling some people's dreams of no longer being the only sentient beings on this earth, but also providing militaries with additional manpower in the form of strength enhancement, canine-like senses, or even echo-location if that's possible. Industries taking advantage of the research would eventually profit off the military (usually) at first, later the public just as the helicopter first served the military, then the public. As said, this is a controversial topic due to the fact it makes you have to make a decision on rights, freedoms, and what's ethical in all situations. What costs less, or more, what's the public outlook on isolated pockets of anthropromoprhic soldiers marching amongst regular Humans. Will religions get in the way or support it? Most of all, is that some will see Anthro-gene splicing as an inferior or superior thing, either becoming xenophobic or xenophiles to the very subject...causing outrage among citizens and those whom volunteered/payed to be changed, no matter how drastic. Work laws over equal working rights would have to be made, the sheer amount of changes would be drastic, but (as an Anthro artist and enthusiast) it would most certainly be interesting.

I'm not against GMO's, I think it's a Crowning Achievement of Modern Technology. But like Everything FDA Related it needs to be done in the Right Way with Proper Oversight, Transparency and Long-Term Risk Assessments. There are Some Very Valid Concerns;
1] Worrying That Very Few or Just One Major Corporation will Own(Patented) Just About all the GMO Plants We Grow is a Concern. And that would give them Immense Power if they Control the Food Supply around the World. It Would be Great if GMO Crops would be Developed/Funded by Non Profit Organizations or the Government or the United Nations, Point is that It should be looked at, as a Humanitarian Effort, to Help the Whole World.
2] It's the Whole Ownership & Patenting Area Around GMO Foods Where it Falls Into a Grey Area & Cause for Concern.
3] In Nature the Diversity of Plant Genes is what Allows them to Adapt to New Threats be it (Pest, Diseases, Climate Change, ect.), If you Geneticly Modify all the Corn and then a New Disease Pops Up that Effects All the Countrys Geneticly Modified Corn Then our Whole Food Supply Risks geting Wiped Out or Contaminated. You Run that Risk when you make Every Plant's Genetic Makeup Identical. Hence, Natural Selection doesn't Occur.
4] There Needs to be Oversight and Regulations put in Place. So the Bio-Tech Company's Don't Make Sterile Seeds Just so they can Price Gouge the Farmer's every year because they hold all the Patents to all the GMO's. Thus Having a Major Monopoly on our Food.
5] However Unlikely There Could Potentially be Acts of Bio-Warfare where Someone Creates a Disease Aimed at our GMO crops & It could Cascade Throughout the Whole Country, Killing All Crops & Our Entirely Food Supply!
6] Most Corporation's Purposely Manufacture Inherent Design Flaws in there Product so It Won't Last Forever, So They can Sell you the Same Product Again. Just think of Apples Ipod as an example, they designed the battery's to Fail & Die Just After your Warranty is over. This is the inherent evil in capitalism when it Comes to Things Essential to Life. And Knows If You Create/Design a Product That is "Too Good" and it Lasts a Long Time, Then you Won't have Customers Buying It Again. It's All About The $ & Max Profits.
7] This is Why Things like Food, Water, Medicine and Other Things Essential to Survival Need to be Protected, and We Need New Updated Laws Regulating GMO's and Protecting Everyone.
(Side Note)
Just Imagine If Armed Conflict in the World was Over and We All Focused our Energy & Effort Towards the Overall Good of Humanity by Advancing Technology & Our Understanding of Our Universe. What We Could Acomplish As a Whole Unified Planet.....

I'm as environmentalist as one could be but I start to go towards disagreeing with the health part of the anti-GMO ideology, as multiple studies prove me wrong (yay science!).
However, as brilliant as this video is (and it is!), I'm still against GMOs, and that's for reasons I think this video really should've talked about.
Indeed, this video is more about the direct health effects of GMOs rather than them being good or bad, as mentioned in the title. I think the big thing Kurzgesagt missed can be put under "the effects of the GMO industry": As I said I trust scientists on the fact that GMOs themselves aren't bad, but the whole economic thing is dreadful as big companies like Monsanto have been putting patents on life-sustaining crops for farmers in developing countries, which forces them to buy every year at a high price crops that sometimes do not reproduce and/or require the farmers to buy expensive chemicals they haven't needed before. Soon enough, the greed of these massive companies bring thousands upon thousands of farmer to debt, bankruptcy, and suicide. And even if they do not commit suicide, how fucked up is that? Even in countries as developed as France, replanting saved grain and/or exchanging grains is illegal since you don't directly buy it from "state approved companies", and this can lead to enormous fines.
The second problem about the GMO industry is biodiversity: As crops become less of a free thing, industry-aimed farms start to engage in monoculture, which is really bad for the environment and requires even more GMO, since diverse crops defend each other. The fact that they defend each other also may mean that we do not need GMOs if we mix crops and cultivate multiple species of the same plant at the same time: Plants work like animals in that a high level of diversity makes for healthier individuals (I'm not making this up, I heard and read about it a couple of times, and I wish I could give you sources in English but I don't know of any). This is not feasible in enormous farms but if we come back to a system of smaller and more local farms it totally is (and BOOM, it also creates jobs in poorly populated areas).

Ultimately I think GMOs are just an overkill and are the wrong way of dealing with our problems, we just need to rely less on industry and more on local farmers ...and free the crops! :D
Farms should also start expanding Up instead of Out.

Really great video guys! I agree completely except for one thing. You make it sound like GMOs are the only or the best way to feed humanity in the future. It looks to me like we should first consider the effects on the environment of the things we eat. The truth is that animal agriculture is the biggest, or second biggest (depending on who you ask), emitter of green house gasses. Much of the reason why we are in this situation is because people in developed countries eat way too much meat. Cows in specific require a lot of resources to grow (2500 gallons of water are required to produce 1 pound of beef).

In my opinion, people should reduce their dependence on animal agriculture to meet their protein needs. Right now, companies like Beyond Meat are producing plant-based meats that contain as much protein as the usual animal-based meats. There are also burgers created on labs using stem cells. I feel like these efforts in reshaping the way we feed humanity are not receiving the attention they deserve. Instead we only focus on GMOs as the only solution. I don't mean to insult GMOs, I think they are great and I do believe that they'll be essential in the future, but they are not the only solution.

Please consider this and I hope that you'll make a video about this later.

Further reading:
http://blog.ucsusa.org/doug-boucher/beef-and-the-paris-agreement-changing-what-we-eat-to-stop-causing-climate-change

I support GMO technology but make a personal decision not to consume GMO foods because I do not consume any synthetic herbicides or pesticides, which are inherent to many GMO plants. The reason for this is a very devoted adherence to zero-tolerance pesticide-free dietary restrictions that my family has continued since the 1960s. In the 50s and 60s there was a very widely used synthetic pesticide in the US known as DDT, and it became increasingly known to cause many health problems in both humans and animals, causing cancer and reproductive issues and damaging the environment. Agricultural use was eventually banned, but before that happened my grandparents began growing their own vegetables and vowed never to buy foods grown with non-natural pesticides ever again, lest the industry make the same mistake.

Reasons why fear of GMOs are unfounded:
1) GMOs are safe.
2) Monsanto could disappear from the face of the earth, and GMOs would still be safe.
3) Agent Orange, Roundup, and terminator seeds have nothing to do with the safety of GMOs.
4) Hundreds, or thousands, of scientific bodies worldwide, both governmental and independent, have not all been corrupted or paid off or bullied into producing a consensus that GMOs are safe.
5) The "Non-GMO Project" is composed of, ahem, corporate shills. Shills for organic companies. Source: their own Web site, not a critical site: https://www.nongmoproject.org/about/organization/board-of-directors/
6) Finally, GMOs are safe.

This channel seems to like to draw conclusions on inconclusive realms of science. It is a logical fallacy at best. Many studies on GMOs remain inconclusive and the full extent of the effects of GMOs both good/bad. There are many studies that prove over a 30 day trial period there have been no noticeable signs of harm even on a rather microscopic level.

Yet... the video fails to comment on the fact that many of the harmful chemicals or "toxins" (which are actually harmful to humans) have been found in maternal and fetal blood in women. (https://previa.uclm.es/Actividades/repositorio/pdf/doc_3721_4666.pdf )

as well as the possibility that some of these genes may be passed into our own genetic structure over time. However something like that won't be able to be conclusively proven until a given state of time (http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0069805 )

The list goes on. This is a really unhealthy approach to science as it fails to recognise both the positives and the negatives GMOs can have on our potential health and society (a good example of the societal effects is the crisis in india caused by GMO crops).

You should be ashamed. Dirty and backhanded science. Enough of the bias in science. Lets appreciate the positives and the negatives which science has to offer and get away from this dogmatic and stigmatic approach to a broader scope.

People who think they have a "gluten allergy" should try to eat bread that wasn't treated with glyphosate.

In the argument that glyphosate is nearly harmless, I find that it is only valid until we apply it to something we eat a lot: wheat. After doing testing with friends and family, I have found that people who state that they are "allergic to gluten" are actually reacting to glyphosate. This is because Americans typically eat bread that is treated with pesticides. But after these same people ate bread that stated they their wheat supplier did not use pesticides, all of their "gluten related reactions" disappeared.

The country of Italy does not treat their wheat with glyphosate, and one of friends who studied abroad said that she could eat all the delicious pastries and such she wanted, as long as it was made with Italian wheat.

Just a thought.

I greatly dissent with this video and I'll explain why:
Firstly, it doesn't refer to the problem that weeds and insects quickly develop resistance to herbicides, pesticides and "natural" pesticides made by GM crops. This poses a threat to the environment since it implies the use of ever rising amounts of agrochemicals onto the foods we eat.
Secondly, it states that GM crops can yield more which is absolutely wrong. Look for the "Farming Systems Trial" study by the Rodale Institute (a 30 years study) which concluded that organic crops can yield the same amount or even more than that of GMO crops that require synthetic chemicals, they can be more resistant to climate change and droughts, and take into account the natural processes that occur in the whole biosphere that naturally regenerate the soil and its fertility.
Thirdly, it doesn't consider the fact that these chemicals contaminate underground waters and whole ecosystems (like the change of gender of frogs) and end up destroying a whole natural food chain (that include many insects that serve as food to many animals).
In conclusion, I think it's a dangerous thing to consider GMOs safe and as the most viable option to feed our growing requirements of food in the world since this is the exact same argument Monsanto uses to sustain their argument defending their use.

technological advancement is neither good nor bad, it's the logical progression of having cognisant beings walking the planet. we should however be weary of technologies that can have such a profound impact on the entire globe because we live in a world where economic profit is often wagered against the value of human life. the safest way i see this technology safely moving forward for the betterment of mankind is if research is open to public consumption and it's not owned by monopolistic interests. i can't think of any other way for there to be trust

The issue I hear about most is with farmers vs. corporations on GMO patents.

Imagine you own a farm and a corporation's field opens up right next to yours. They use their own patented crop instead of the crop you use, but otherwise the crops are identical.

If, for any reason, any seed or crop of THEIR field grows on YOURS? You're liable for a lawsuit about patent theft. And therein lies the rub- GMO or not, plants are still plants, and they'll grow wherever they can possibly get access to. Stopping any potential seed from a neighboring farm from crossing onto your multi-acre land, 365 days a year, is functionally impossible, but that very inability to do so leaves farmers helpless against inevitable corporate litigation that ruins them.

There's nothing wrong with GMOs, health-wise- they've done more for fighting world hunger than traditional agriculture ever has. But GMOs do not come naturally or easily, and that begs questions about fair use of their production and management.

In short, GMOs are gonna make stronger organism that we cant fight because we decided to play mother nature.

It is not the GMOs themselves that are the problem, but the way companies like Monsanto monopolize the the technology and use exploitative tacticts. If we can address the following issues, GMOs will be a benefit to human society.
1. Stop focusing on modifying plants to be resistant to pesticides and herbicides. This just encourages the use of more chemicals that bio-accumulate in our watersheds. Instead focus on traits like increased yields and drought resistance.
2. Don't allow companies like Monsanto to sue farmers for having modified plants in their fields that blew in on the wind.
3. Stop focusing on monoculture fields with no genetic diversity.

The problem is not GMOs, but the exploitative, capitalist global food system that allows this amazing technology to be exploited, particularly in developing nations.

What I'm more worried about is unforeseen consequences. We act like we know everything about how genes work. Even if we did, we can't possibly predict all of the possible problems it might have to the very complex and fragile ecosystem if some "rogue" plant spreads. It might be quite unlikely something like this would happen, but there is a small possibility to do a lot of damage if things get out of hand. It is quite different when the whole ecosystem has evolved in equilibrium for millions of years and when you put something in the wild that's produced in the lab with specific gene modifications.
In short we should be careful and keep in mind that we are still learning how nature works and are far from figuring it all out.

I love your stuff but I hate to be a bit of a downer right now... But your distinctions between lab-tech GMOs and selective-breeding GMOs while technically accurate oversimplifies the processes to the point of being borderline dis-informational.

Selective breeding (which, yes, is technically a way of genetically modifying various organisms) relies on the processes of nature itself to accomplish the feat. True, it is "random" in the sense you're presenting it but the anti-GMO fiends out there will scream bloody hell at you because it is like comparing a quince to a red delicious apple. While they're both fruits and share common traits/lineage, they're not the same. So, say I have a collection of silver-foxes (I'm sure you know where I'm going with this) and two pairs show more passive traits... I breed those and don't allow the aggressive foxes to breed. I continue this process over multiple generations... In the end I find that not only does domestication affect their physiology in rather interesting ways, it is using the natural process (the silver-fox version of the horizontal mambo) to achieve this process.

How it differs from lab-tech GMOs is that with a lab-tech GMO, instead of taking control of the process of nature to selectively breed (by using the natural way that foxes breed) to achive the results I want, I'm reaching into their very genome to alter their DNA in ways that may or may not have occurred naturally in nature. So, while I could create a chimera from a fox parent that is, essentially, domesticated (by removing segments of DNA that may lead to aggressive behaviour and replacing it with DNA that would induce those domesticated traits to manifest) they are not using the natural process of the "insert tod A into vixen B" method.

I'm not one of those "ALL GMOs ARE BAD MMMKAY" types. I'm more the "as long as we're not creating a transgenic plague and it is actually tested to be safe, I'm cool" types (ref: that bacterium that almost sterilized the earth.)

(This all said, I'm not erasing the potential concerns that anti-GMO types bring up. Some of those concerns are valid and it's not cool to just hand-wave them all away because "do you want people to stave?" fear-mongering. But this is not an issue that we can allow ourselves to think in a polar manner on. This is a nuanced and complicated issue.)

A thought occurs. If we have super carbon dioxide consuming trees to such a point that it actually started to reverse climate change, wouldn't that mean that we'd eventually have a problem with too much oxygen. It sounds ridiculous I know but think about it for a moment. Fossil fuels won't be around forever, they will eventually be scarce enough that they will become impractical. Say we crack the code to Nuclear fusion in the next 20 years and it quickly becomes our number one source of electricity. Is it unrealistic to think that the carbon footprint would be so low that the trees would actually overload us with oxygen, which of course would lead to a more flammable environment? Is it possible to "turn off" the pronounced high CO2 consumption trait once we're in a good place?

If the GMO crops have an artificially engineered advantage in say, harsher climates, does that not give them a disruptive edge when introduced in naturally balanced ecosystems? Would that not imply a loss of biodiversity in the long-run? After all, if we're introducing them to counteract the effects of climate change, since they'd out-compete traditional plants which are not as well adapted (since they need millions of years to do so).

We may understand and know well how to tailor plants to do great things but I'm not sure if that extends to putting them alongside natural processes. Perhaps there's a parallel here between invasive species and GMOs, since I'm not sure we really understand the consequences of putting something new into a very intricate - and old - system. This is all purely conjecture from my loose understanding of ecology, so I'm curious if anyone better informed in this area could enlighten us on whether such concerns are real.

However, eventhough gmo's have a lot of potential, we have to be very cautious with them. This video presents BT crops as a good and harmless invention, decreasing the usage of insecticides. In reality, the use of insecticides only decreases temporaly until the pests become resistant to it. BT won't kill all the pests, but will leave some individuals alive. They will struggle to survive but will be able to breed and soon we have a population that has evolved immune to the poison - and then, once again, an increasing amounts of insecticides have to be sprayed on the crop to keep the pests away.

While this video is a nice introduction, it is one-sided and completely ignores the reason why several developed countries have banned / not approved GMOs at least to some extent. The main issue with GMOs is that there are risks we can't manage, as we don't have complete control on what we're doing. This has lead several countries in restricting GMO use based on the precautionary principle. One issue for example is the horizontal gene transfer (in a few words, modified genes being transmitted to other plants not via reproduction but via bacteria / viruses), which needs to be better understood as it could cause modified genes to be spread into the wild. That wasn't even mentioned in this video. Additionally, a lot of things are possible with GMOs, which could have massive impacts on ecosystems and lower the gene pool. GMOs may be the future, but our understanding isn't up to par yet. So is fear of GMO unfounded? We don't know.

Concerning genetically inserting Bt into crops there are two sides to consider. As a gardener, I realize the insertion of one of the safest pest control would initially make application much easier, efficient, and less expensive. As most of us know of the curative properties of the miracle drug penicillin which was used on almost everything and saved many lives. Later we discovered infectious diseases were becoming immune to this miracle drug making it ineffective possibly for an indefinite period.

Herbicide resistant plants would allow stronger herbicides to be used, which weeds may also form an immunity. As sure as nitrogen, phosphorous, and potash are absorbed into crops these herbicides will be absorbed into the plants. Whether the plants be tobacco, textiles, or tomatoes the increase of these toxins might causes unwanted reactions.

One possible solution might be to regularly alternate crops with non GMO crops, alternate years that GMOs would be sold to farmers, or use GMO crops only when problems are getting out of hand. Relying on farmers to self regulate and refuse more profitable methods might be naive. Extra government restricted seeds might be bought and saved for the following year.

In my opinion the video missed a few problems GMOs. I don't see the downsides not so much on health, like the video said it's more a less a modern form of traditional plant breeding, but more on the management side.

For example one problem is that GMOs are very succesfull (at least on short term) so the quickly are wide spreed and many farmers use more or less the same crops. They could for example be resisstend to an pesticide or produce it so big population of insects will die, but not all of them, some will adapte or are natural ressistant against the pesticides. They will start a new poplulation and spread rapidly with nothing to stop them or slow them, because every farmer uses the same crops. A country could loss a lot of food at once when something like this happens.

Another problem is with the golden rice kind of GMOs. They are health true, but most of the time those extra nutrients are not necessary when you have an normal diet. A few extra nutrients are usually not harmful for your body, soil they are. The plant doesn't produce those nutrients magicly out of nothing the take them from the soil and than the soil doesn't have any nutrients for the next year. You could counter that with fertilization, but that's expansive and brings a whole lot of problems with them as well, like depleting sources of phosphor or the transfer of to much fertilizers into other ecosystems like rivers and the sea where they cause problems. A better way would be a Crop rotation that also help the soil to regenerate, you get more out of the field and don't need much fertilizer.

The problems of world hunger won't be solved with GMOs, usually GMOs are standardized crops for standardized soild. But most of the world doesn't have standardized soild. You could create for each soil an own crop, but we already have tens of thousend crops which work on thos thousends of soils, so why reinventing the wheel. The real problems are on the management side, production for export and not the local people, to high meat consumption (70% of our crops go into meat production), big companies that block out small locals, food waste and loss of old knowlage of local crops and soils.

Most of my agruments are not that GMOs themselfs are bad, but the way the are used or rather the way our foodsystem functions right now and GMOs only work in this system, eventhough the become cheaper to develop a few big companies will never be able to provide some much varrity or react so fast to environmental changes like small local farmers can.

While the scientific arguments were convincing, little attention was paid to the ontological and social issues related to current GMO industries and applications: copyright over seeds, economic dependence of farmers to highly unregulated, government-lobbying monopolies, menace to biodiversity and local species, etc. While the golden rice could be a good example of good GMO use, there are dozens of examples of the opposite, like the mass suicides of indian farmers linked to gmo-related social consequences, or south american farmers being forced to buy seeds from a monopoly that has absolute control over market prices, while they could formerly reproduce them from their own crops. Imagine what it is to an already-empoverished farmer to have to buy seeds of something that was naturally free and abundant. It's like having to buy air, or water. Public scientific discourse is inherently linked to its social, economic and symbolic applications, surroundings and consequences, and you have been scientifically irresponsible today by ignoring those.

Ancient farming methods often are much more sustainable since they take into account the local climate and work with nature. GMOs are an additional tool. They should be wisely and in harmony with the local environment and people. It's a complex issue and like most complex issues it requires an holistic approach.

I get the video's points, but three major arguments against GMOs are not being addressed:

_Patent property and the notion that corporations own DNA, therefore own every plant that contains this DNA by proxy (including in case of cross polination, which is THE argument used against golden rice)
_Diversity reduction. I don't feel like I have to explain this one further.
_And then the more philosophical question of humans playing god. Naomi Klein describes it pretty well when it comes to geoengineering for instance; thinking that human activity overcoming natural activity is going to fix the effect of human activity on natural systems is not just a semantic paradox, it's a healthy questioning of human ego.

Obviously I lean against GMOs as you may notice, but I would have been very keen on seeing these questions addressed here because I feel we would have gotten into the actual contention points, however Kurzgesagt position might end up being.

I expect a more balanced approach; e.g.
1) Large corporations conducting law suits against farmers that have their fields "infected" by GMO plants - as if they stole the seeds
2) Transgenes - genes from different animals or plants might cause effects we cannot expect when they combine to create phenotype effects
3) Mutations - when huge amounts of plants are mass produced - mutations are more probable. Gene splicing is a mutagen accelerator - which might cause rapid changes (e.g. almost all bananas in my region are genetically identical - a mutation will spread much quickly in a homogeneous population
4) Bio diversity is hindered by successful GMOs - seed banks are under funded and we are about to loose many important types of plants that could help a population recover a disease or a powerful pest

The list goes on.

I'm not sure that a dichotomy of GOOD vs BAD is the correct approach, but I would have like to hear the anti-GMO side claims stated more clearly

With crossbreeding, chances are that everything you wanted DID naturally occur within the species or a relative of it, just not all together so you just forced natures hand a bit by getting those with traits you want to do the deed. Great video. This is one of those debates that's hard to have a reasoned argument about because people seem to have different goals/starting points when talking about it. For me, what matters isn't what's "natural," it's what can help human life. Like you said, GMO's have this tremendous potential to help. My concerns with them mostly have to do with the business element you mentioned, but also a concern about unintended environmental consequences. The environment is a really complex system, and making changes to it often results in reactions we weren't expecting. For example, (not based on a real situation, just a hypothetical) what if it turned out that the bugs that the insecticide plants killed off were important to some other part of the ecosystem and then down the road this causes another problem? Now, of course humans have been making these kinds of changes for a long time, however the difference here is how quickly the change can occur. Domesticating an animal or crop takes generations, once one of these GMOs are produced you could replace the entire crop set in a few years if everyone bought into it. So if there are potential harms to it, they could happen to quickly for us to respond to them.


This doesn't mean we shouldn't keep developing and researching this technology, I just think it warrants additional caution/scrutiny before we actually put new untested crops into the environment. (Obviously anything that's already been tested is probably fine.)

Thank you for your nuanced video, I have a a couple of thoughts though.

Some genetic modification can be extremely useful, like the golden rice mentioned in this video. Also, since blight wiped out nearly all American chestnut trees in the early 1900s, people have been trying to bring them back by back-breeding with the Chinese chestnut to get a gene resistant to blight. This is a process that takes generations (of trees and humans) to get a chestnut tree that has the Chinese chestnut's resistance to blight but resembles American Chestnuts in all other ways. Now there's a possibility of simply inserting a resistant gene and skipping the long process. Very hopeful for bringing back a tree that is so important to American forest ecology.

On the other hand, you didn't mention several concerns people have with staple crop GMOs like corn and soybeans. GMOs are generally expensive and quickly lose their effectiveness for the same reason simply spraying herbicides loses it's effectiveness: pesticide resistance. American farmland is now breeding super weeds that are immune to glyphosate just like the GMO crops around them. If you spray millions of acres a year with glyphosate, the weeds adapt or die and a lot of them are adapting. Farmers have to spray more to keep up, and we're back on the same pesticide treadmill we were without GMOs. And while I agree that glyphosate is much less dangerous then some things farmers can spray, there is a possible cancer risk according to the WHO, and ALL of our corn and soybeans are sprayed with it now.

The proliferation of glyphosate spraying has also directly impacted monarch butterfly numbers, since milkweed (which is the only host the larva will eat) is unfortunately not one of the plants that have developed an immunity to the constant spraying. Other pollinators have felt the impacts as well and bee populations are crashing around the world. I know you touched on this briefly by talking about mono-cultures, but it bears mentioning again.

As long as GMOs are used to proliferate mono-cultures, they're actually more harmful to environment (because they're so efficient) and slowly lose effectiveness over time like other pesticides.

It goes without saying, honestly, that GMOs are important for our future. The fears people have for them really should be directed at some of the current issues with our agriculture system; we use herbicides and pesticides en-masse, and as a result we have crops that are trying to absorb food from soil that is no longer nutrient-rich. Bees find it difficult to pollinate pesticide-ridden food, and it has resulted in a significant drop in their numbers. Alternatives that are currently being developed - 'organic food', for example - aren't able to feed everyone on the planet 'and' provide space for humans to live, not to mention wildlife reserves, national parks, and other places that people want to protect. So if we can find a way to create a type of plant that we can force pests to avoid while allowing other organisms to survive, we will have effectively found a way to kill two birds with one stone.

More importantly though, it's going to be next to impossible to produce crops or raise livestock on other planets unless we genetically modify them first. Currently the way we have planned for food to get to Mars is by growing it there, but people on Mars are going to have health problems without a balanced diet. Shipping meat and other goods to them will be expensive (not to mention gross, because the most efficient way to get it up there is by either freeze-drying it or liquefying it into a paste), and even if we developed rockets capable of shipping larger organisms it'll be next to impossible to send live cows, sheep, pigs, or other such animals into space. Not to mention the fact that, unlike us humans, other animals will have a much harder time adapting to new and harsh environments, so there's no guarantee that future generations of these livestock colonists will be able to provide the food needed for growth. Really the best solution would be to modify an organism at the genetic level so that they could be best adapted to survive, as well as provide humans the food that we need to function.

I do agree (and did prior to this video) that GMOs should be legalised in Europe. I'd seen the manifesto of Nobel Laureates you provided before and that was a big factor in me looking into it.

I would not wholeheartedly embrace them as you do though. I'd have the following concerns:

-lab error: we accept that medecine is a risk but extending that to food seems difficult. A rare occurence admittedly but it's a difficult change/risk to accept psychologically.
-irreversible: in case of said lab error or even simple short-sightedness, change in circumstances, quirky interaction with the eco-system that couldn't be predicted, the process cannot be reversed unless there are terminator seeds. The genie is out of the bottle and won't always go neatly back in.
-It is a way for big industries to create monopolies over the food we eat (be it via control over the research or control over the seeds themselves). This one isn't inevitable but there's a lot of work that needs to be done to prevent this before we take the leap
I agree that GMO's can be good. Higher yields, pest resilient, and resistance against pesticides, but wouldn't we end up with the same problem that we are running into today with antibiotics?

Important criticism of GMOs the video hasn't adressed

The genes can in principle travel from one species to another, the chances are pretty low, but it can happen. In the video they visualize it as a tiny square meter of GMO crops, with a huge buffer layer around it, reducing the chances. In reality the entire field would be filled with GMO crops.

A lot of insect species are already hurt by our pesticides, and if "pesticide" genes were to spread to wildlife plants, this would fucking assrape our poor tiny bees and other non-mosquito insects.

Instead of making in built pesticides, there is another alternative, which is increased resistance to pesticides. Again, if the genes can spread to weeds, this means that every so many years or so we'll have to replace the pesticides we use.
here before trending

But wait, if the plants suddenly become toxic to the insects, what would be left for them to eat? Would the remaining survivors move to other plants to eat? Or will the sudden decrease of the insects give way for those that developed a resistance to the BT Protein? If they ever become resistant to this, then what would we do about those insects?
It is a similar issue to the problems of the misuse of antibiotics that can develop superbugs, have there been any studies done regarding this potential issue?

On a side note, I personally think that GMOs are a double edged sword. It can both be beneficial or harm, depending on who uses it and for what. While really helpful in the right hands, it could potentially lead to catastrophic effects in the wrong hands.

A lot of people are against the idea because it's a very new concept, and the idea of changing the very traits of an organism is scary. Pesticides not only are extremely harmful to bugs, but they are also are very harmful towards humans. Pesticides absorb into the plant over time, and is not just something you can simply just "rinse off". Not only that, but people also have been concerned about wether it is even safe to eat a Genetically Modified Gene in the first place. I don't agree at all. there are so many little factors that go into a plant that GMOs don't account for.

But selective breeding does account for. One example was corn. corn use to be able to call its own resistant predators from the soil called nematodes (there are two kinds of nematodes ones that eat the roots of plant bad ones, and one that eats other insects around the roots of plants, corn was able to call for help for the latter). Now the GMO corn relies on its own engineered pesticides BT wich has been used by plant already its a naturally occurring bacteria that plants create a symbiotic relationship with for small periods of time to help prevent bug infestation naturally but now corn has it running in its DNA and prevents that plant to rely on any predatory insect to help it fight back disease. so corn no longer can create that relationship with nematodes and if you were to look up the soil food web wich is our current understanding of how nature creates nutrients for plants you would see nematodes are a critical component of the soil and sets the stage for a later production of nutrients. Plants that were selective for breeding were able to call and produce this kind of relationships faster and better than their previous generation. while most GMOS who have BT kill any insect that decides to eat the plant wich, in turn, changes the way the soil functions causing us to use more synthetic salts and or stronger pesticides when they do get a virus or bug infestation.

There are already plants that fixate nitrogen from the air into the soil without us trying to engineer them there are methods of growing that help prevents a disease from spreading. one example of this was bananas they were completely wiped out from a virus due to monocropping ( growing the same plant all in one field multiple times). and so we had to engineer and breed out a new banana which we know today but we still mono-crop the plant and never diversify with the plant. creating a breeding ground for viruses to attack and now we are seeing another virus starting to take out our current banana plant. even genetic engineering won't prevent the devastation of monocropping when a virus or bug become resistant to all the pesticides that we put into our plants.

But selective breeding and nature already showed us an answer to these things you have to have a diverse plant production so when viruses and disease take place they won't be able to spread from plant to plant. you have to use plants that but nutrients back into the soil and plants that are great for disease resistance these plants call for predatory insects and bacteria or fungi to help fight the disease for all the plants they are growing close to. and we have to keep creating more desirable plants by breeding the plants together. in return, we get plants that grow bigger faster and strong but also improve the soil and relationships with its surrounding crops.

GMO doesn't understand that a plant is only one part of a system. we have to look at the fungus and bacteria and insects that rely on the plant to thrive because the plant also relies on these relationships to thrive and survive.

The equivalency of selective breeding to GMO is not a good one. You can selectively breed apples to get a particularly sweeter or bigger apple, but in the end, you will only get an apple. You are limited by the collective total traits already IN the genetic pool of the apple species. With GMOs, you are introducing Generics that were NEVER part of the apple gene pool from other species like oranges or Jelly fish. The Unintended consequences of such an act can Never be determined. You could cause all kinds of mutations and changes that could render your GMO apple harmful (b/c of Allergies), useless (b/c of poisons) or even extinct (like the Gros Michel Banana)

One need only look at What happened when we tried to cross African and European Bees and the level of Chaos that introduced in our environment. Couple that with the Business/Money incentive of Big Agro and you could be setting yourself up for a MAJOR ecological disaster that might be worse than anything we can think of at this time.

While I like the argument as a whole (especially as a means to save our planet and deal with climate change), I think you guys glossed over the issue of contamination and terminator seeds too much. If you use terminator seeds, then the farmers are beholden to the companies that sell them seeds and instead of gaining capital from the seeds produced from their crops instead lose assets when they have to buy new seeds every season. If we don't use terminator seeds, then cross breeding and contamination can occur, which you guys kind of dismiss (To be fair, I haven't gone into your sources but are relying on my knowledge from debating this in a tournament years ago.). The reason why this is such a big deal in the status quo is because these GMO seeds are patented by their producers like Monsanto and DuPont, and there are documented lawsuits made by these two against farmers who never had a contract with them but ended up with their crops on their farms because of contamination. I believe there is also documentation of strongman tactics used by Monsanto against cotton farmers in India. This could go under the argument that you make that anti-GMO sentiment is really dissent against the pre-existing agricultural structure, especially in the US, but if we want to truly be able to reap the benefits of GMOs we need to deal with these issues so that we don't end up with to-big-to-fail agricultural hegemonies...

The video is very excellent, but the "All foods are GMO" angle is kind of bullshit. There's a big difference between selective breeding and transgenic organisms. "GMO" is too broad a term to be useful when discussing its merits and risks. Obviously all crops are genetically modified in the sense that there's a selection pressure present from humans. Surely there's a meaningful distinction to be made between organisms where we've selected the genes we want (by conventional breeding or genetic engineering) and ones where we have introduced genes from different organisms? Genetic engineering has a lot of promise and will no doubt accomplish great things for us, but the precautionary principle must be applied.

There are big issues you forgot to address. If we genetically modified plants to be resistant to pests, pesticides and weedicides; wouldn't this cause the evolution of more resistant pests and weeds? What would happen if some of these pests had such an evolutionary advantage that they began to swarm causing mass devastation of not just GM crops but non-GM crops as well? Imagine if 90% of our plants share a common genome, wouldn't that reduce genetic diversity to the point where a single virus could have the potential of killing the majority of all GM crops? Speaking of which, what if such a virus was engineered as a military weapon? What would happen of our attitude toward GM crops became so tolerable that we began genetically modifying insects to further aid these crops and what are the consequences (as in good or bad) if we did? I believe in the technology but I am skeptical as to whether we are ready to use it.

Edit: I forgot to mention other problems as well. If a GM plant is introduced to an ecosystem where it has a significant evolutionary advantage, could this greatly impact the ecosystem in unpredictable and extreme ways such as an ecological imbalance cause some species to go extinct? Finally and on a more socio-economic problem, if GM plants are introduced to a third world country with unstable political institutes, is it possible that during periods of natural disaster or intended sabotage that the few individuals who control these GM crop be at a political advantage leading to further destabilisation of the country?

Two criticisms:
1) Artificial selection is different in kind from genetic engineering. Genetic engineering is a rapid process which does not respect genetic precedent; it is therefore a difficult phenomenon for other organisms to adapt to.
2) Saying "genetic modification is not harmful" is like saying "chemicals are not harmful". Well, some are, and some aren't, and the harmfulness can depend even on the person, not just the species.

Genetic engineering offers a lot of promise, but I'd feel a lot better about GMOs if the modifications were open-source and there were a theory for the consequences. It's an inevitable technology, but like artificial general intelligence, it carries the kind of risk that comes with paradigm-shifts. Unlike AI, GMOs are inherently self-replicating machines, so if you thought a mere superintelligence-in-a-box was scary...

When it comes to GMOs, the most common concern I here is about pesticides, but that's not really a GMO specific issue. Almost all crops, even organic ones, will used pesticides of some kind, and there are some studies (and even an example in the video) showing that GM crops can actually reduce pesticide use. I really appreciate that the video characterises pesticides as a product of the agricultural industry and not a concern of GMOs in and of themselves.

Also, farmers regularly bought seeds for certain crops, like corn, well before GMOs. Continually buying seeds grown from a favourable hybrids preserves the favourable traits and keeps the crops uniform, making them easier to maintain.

My biggest problem with GMO's is not with the food, but with the regulation surrounding it. It's way to easy at the moment for companies that produce GMO's to monopolize (part of) the market thanks to the regulations surrounding it. Farmers are also to my knowledge required to buy new seeds for every harvest or at least pay for every harvest (this might be based on outdated/incorrect information). This means that a bad harvest for a GMO farmer can bankrupt them if they haven't had the chance to save enough money.

Until the laws and regulations surrounding GMO's have been significantly improved in favour of the consumer, I won't be actively supporting the sale of GMO crops. The food they produce is perfectly fine but the industry is not set up in a healthy way.

Guys, I love your videos and the way you do your things, but I'm kinda disappointed by this one! It's crystal clear now that GMO's are safe to consume and as you say, it's not the engineering the hot spot of the debate, is the actual applicative method that would follow the capitalistic/consumer society environment, in which the GMO's as we intend them to be were born in the first place,  that scare the sceptical. On the top of that, something you didn't mention: genetic diversity. In the end of the video, you expressed the rightful hope that by embracing GMO technology we would be likely capable of fixing most of the environmental issues we've been generating for a long time now, but there's a blindness in it that really sets me off. By introducing this kind of organisms worldwide, you are stressing another delicate equilibrium between plants and all their pathogens , between plants and plants, and between plants and insects! These are 3 fuses that would be automatically triggered by embracing such a technology and I don't see any reminder of errors being made in the past for us to follow....meaning that the first thing we, as a species, do wrong, won't be perceived as such just like has happened with many innovations we brought ourselves for a better life. You're work is amazing, I'd love to see another video on this particular issue, but I've not seen enough literature covering the argument yet, so let's be patient and participate to the great work until more questions are answered. Love you, keep rocking and put everything in nutshells :)

While I agree with GMOs being great, and a very powerful for us and the enviroment, I would like to comment on one specific thing you glossed over.

The reason past GMO crops should be commonly accepted, is due to the huge amount of evidence saying they are safe. I agree with this, however this poses a few problems. Is the technology good enough to pump out new plants, all well and tested, before their use becomes too late?

At what point does GMO testing become redundant? What is the current accuracy of creating genes? What may the genes mutate into, and how might they interfere with other crops and species? If our regulations slack too much, disasters may happen, where the GMO species could become invasive. Evidence of ignorant use of biology, like introduction of red foxes in Australia for hunting, rendered many species to endangered levels.

The path to glory is thin, and slipping off of it may tarnish GMO's reputation to the extent the public may no longer tolerate it. There is no solution to this, but time. One of the best ways to change public opinion is to let new technology sink in, and demonstrate it's safety and power, before advancing. I see no other universal technique, but if you have a suggestion, gimme one!
